verses.latin: Et concepit mulier, et peperit filium in tempore, et in hora, quam dixerat Eliseus ei.
verses.english: And indeed, the woman conceived and bore a son at the very time and in the season that Elisha had promised her.

verses.latin: Crevit autem puer. Et cum esset aliquando, et egrederetur ad patrem suum ad messores,
verses.english: The boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father, who was with the reapers in the field,

verses.latin: ait patri suo: Caput meum dolet, caput meum dolet. At ille ait puero: Tolle eum, et duc ad matrem suam.
verses.english: and he cried out to his father: 'My head, my head aches! My head, my head aches!' His father then said to one of the servants: 'Carry him home, and take him to his mother.'

verses.latin: Qui cum tulisset, et duxisset ad matrem suam, posuit eum super genua sua usque ad meridiem, et mortuus est.
verses.english: So the servant carried him and brought him to his mother. She held him on her knees until midday, and then he died.

verses.latin: Ascendit autem, et posuit eum super lectulum hominis Dei, et clausit ostium, et egressa est.
verses.english: Then she went up to the room, placed him on the bed of the man of God, closed the door, and left.

verses.latin: Et vocavit virum suum, dicens: Mitte mihi, obsecro, unum de pueris, et asinam, ut curram ad hominem Dei, et revertar.
verses.english: She called her husband, saying: 'Please send me one of the young men and a donkey, so I can hurry to the man of God and return quickly.'

verses.latin: Qui ait: Quam ob causam vadis ad eum? Hodie neomenia, aut sabbatum est? Illa respondit: Pax est.
verses.english: He asked: 'For what reason are you going to him today? Is it the New Moon festival or the Sabbath day?' She replied, cryptically: 'It is well.' —meaning 'All is fine, I will explain later.'

verses.latin: Stravit ergo asinam, et præcepit puero suo: Mina, et propera: ne moreris in eundo, nisi cum dixero tibi.
verses.english: So she saddled the donkey and instructed her servant: 'Drive quickly; do not slow down the pace unless I tell you to.'

verses.latin: Ivit igitur, et venit ad hominem Dei in montem Carmeli: cumque vidisset eam homo Dei e contra, ait ad Giezi puerum suum: Ecce Sunamitis illa.
verses.english: Thus she went and arrived at the man of God, Elisha, on Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to his servant Gehazi: 'Look, it is that Shunammite woman!'

verses.latin: Vade ergo obviam ei, et dic: Rectene se habet, et vir tuus, et filius tuus? Illa respondit: Recte.
verses.english: 'Run now to meet her,' he instructed, 'and ask her: “Is all well with you? Is all well with your husband? Is all well with your son?”' She replied, again briefly: 'All is well.'

verses.latin: Cumque venisset ad virum Dei in montem, apprehendit pedes ejus: et accessit Giezi ut removeret eam. Et ait homo Dei: Dimitte illam: anima enim ejus in amaritudine est, et Dominus celavit a me, et non indicavit mihi.
verses.english: But when she reached the man of God on the mountain, she grasped his feet. Gehazi approached to push her away. But the man of God said: 'Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness. The Lord has hidden it from me and has not revealed it to me.'

verses.latin: Et illa ait: Numquid petii filium a domino meo? Numquid non dixi tibi: Noli me decipere?
verses.english: And she cried out: 'Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say to you: “Do not deceive me”?'

verses.latin: Et ait illi: Accinge lumbos tuos, et tolle baculum meum in manu tua, et vade: si occurreris homini, non salutes eum: et si te salutaverit quispiam, non respondeas illi: et pones baculum meum super faciem pueri.
verses.english: Elisha then said to Gehazi: 'Gird up your loins, take my staff in your hand, and go. If you meet anyone on the way, do not greet them; and if anyone greets you, do not answer them. Place my staff upon the face of the boy.'

verses.latin: Dixitque mater pueri: Vivit Dominus, et vivit anima tua, non dimittam te. Surrexit ergo, et secutus est eam.
verses.english: But the mother of the boy declared: 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you!' So Elisha arose and followed her.

verses.latin: Giezi autem præcesserat eos, et posuerat baculum super faciem pueri, et non fuit vox, nec auditus: reversusque est in occursum ejus, et nuntiavit ei, dicens: Non surrexit puer.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had placed the staff upon the boy's face. But there was no voice, nor any sign of life. So he returned to meet Elisha and reported to him, saying: 'The boy has not awakened.'

verses.latin: Ingressus est ergo Eliseus domum, et ecce puer mortuus jacebat in lectulo ejus.
verses.english: Then Elisha entered the house, and behold, the boy was lying dead on his own bed.

verses.latin: Et ingressus clausit ostium super se, et puerum, et oravit ad Dominum.
verses.english: He went in and closed the door behind himself and the boy, and he prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ascendit, et incubuit super puerum: posuitque os suum super os ejus, et oculos suos super oculos ejus, et manus suas super manus ejus: et extendit se super eum, et calefacta est caro pueri.
verses.english: Then he went up and lay upon the boy, putting his mouth upon his mouth, and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands. He stretched himself out upon him, and the boy's flesh began to grow warm.

verses.latin: Reversusque deambulavit in domo semel atque iterum: et ascendit, et incubuit super eum: et oscitavit puer septem vicibus, et aperuit oculos.
verses.english: Elisha then went down and walked around in the house once more. Then he went up again and stretched himself out upon the boy once more. And the boy sneezed seven times, and then opened his eyes.

verses.latin: Et vocavit Giezi, et dixit ei: Voca Sunamitidem istam. Quae vocata ingressa est ad eum. Qui ait: Tolle filium tuum.
verses.english: Elisha called Gehazi and told him: 'Call this Shunammite woman.' When she was called, she came in to him. He said: 'Take up your son!'

verses.latin: Venit illa, et corruit ad pedes ejus, et adoravit super terram: tulitque filium suum, et egressa est.
verses.english: She came in, fell at his feet, and prostrated herself on the ground in worship. Then she took up her son and went out.

verses.latin: Eliseus autem reversus est in Galgala. Famis autem erat in terra, et filii prophetarum sedebant coram eo: dixitque uni de servis suis: Pone ollam grandem, et coque pulmentum filiis prophetarum.
verses.english: Elisha then returned to Gilgal. There was a severe famine in the land, and the prophet-disciples were sitting before him. He said to one of his servants: 'Put a large pot on the fire, and cook a stew for the prophet-disciples.'

verses.latin: Egressus est autem unus in agrum ut colligeret herbas: invenitque herbam agrestem, et ligavit de ea quasi palmam sylvestrem, et repletum abstulit in tunica sua, et concidit in ollam pulmenti: nesciebant enim quid esset.
verses.english: One of them went out into the field to gather herbs. He found a wild plant and gathered enough of its fruit to fill his cloak, —like wild gourds—. He came back and chopped them into the pot of stew, for they did not know what it was.

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo in viros ut comederent. Cumque gustassent, exclamaverunt, dicentes: Mors in olla, vir Dei, mors in olla. Et non potuerunt comedere.
verses.english: So they served it to the men to eat. But when they tasted the stew, they cried out, saying: 'There is death in the pot, O man of God! There is death in the pot!' And they could not eat it.

verses.latin: Mulier quaedam de uxoribus prophetarum clamavit ad Eliseum dicens: Servus tuus vir meus mortuus est, et tu nosti quia servus tuus timuerat Dominum: et nunc creditor venit ut tollat duos filios meos ad serviendum sibi.
verses.english: A certain woman, one of the wives of the prophets, cried out to Elisha, saying: “Your servant, my husband, is dead. You know that your servant lived in holy fear of the Lord. And now a creditor has come to take my two sons to be his slaves to pay off the debt.”

verses.latin: Et ait ad eam Eliseus: Quid vis ut faciam tibi? Dic mihi, quid habes in domo tua? Et illa respondit: Non habeo ancilla tua quicquam in domo mea, absque oleo modico.
verses.english: And Elisha said to her: “What do you want me to do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?” And she responded: “Your handmaid has nothing in my house, except a small amount of oil.”

verses.latin: Qui ait: Vade, et pete mutuo ab omnibus vicinis tuis vasa vacua non pauca.
verses.english: He said: “Go and borrow many empty vessels from all your neighbors. Make sure there are not just a few.”

verses.latin: Et ingredere, et claude ostium super te, et super filios tuos: et funde de oleo in universa vasa haec: et cum plena fuerint, auferes.
verses.english: Then go inside and shut the door behind you and your sons. Pour the oil into all these vessels. And when they are full, set them aside.”

verses.latin: Abiit itaque mulier, et clausit ostium super se, et super filios suos: illi afferebant vasa, et illa infundebat.
verses.english: So the woman went away and shut the door upon herself and upon her sons. They brought the vessels to her, and she kept pouring.

verses.latin: Cumque plena essent omnia vasa, dixit ad filium suum: Affer mihi adhuc vas. Qui respondit: Non habeo.
verses.english: And when all the vessels were full, she said to her son: “Bring me still another vessel.” He responded: “There are no more.”

verses.latin: Et stetit oleum.
verses.english: And at that moment, the oil stopped flowing.

verses.latin: Venit ergo illa, et indicavit viro Dei. Qui ait: Vende oleum, et redde creditori: tu autem, et filii tui, vivite de reliquo.
verses.english: So she came and told the man of God. He said: “Go, sell the oil, and pay the creditor. You and your sons can then live on the rest of the money.”

verses.latin: Accidit autem ut Eliseus transiret per Sunam: erat autem ibi mulier magna, quae comedit panem ab eo: et cum frequenter transiret, devertebat ad eam ut comederet panem.
verses.english: Now it happened that Elisha was passing through Shunem. And there was a wealthy and influential woman there, who urged him to eat bread with her. So whenever he passed by, he would turn aside to her house to eat bread.

verses.latin: Quae dixit ad virum suum: Puto quod vir Dei sit iste qui transit per nos frequenter, sanctus.
verses.english: And she said to her husband: “I perceive that this man, who passes by us so frequently, is a holy man of God.”

verses.latin: Faciamus ei turriculam parvulam, et ponamus ei in ea lectulum, et mensam, et sellam, et candelabrum, ut cum venerit ad nos, maneat ibi.
verses.english: “Let us make a small upper room for him and put in it a small bed, and a table, and a chair, and a lamp. So that when he comes to us, he may stay there.”

verses.latin: Factum est igitur quadam die, ut veniret Eliseus, et diverteret ad coenaculum, et requiesceret ibi.
verses.english: So it happened one day that Elisha came, and he turned aside to the upper room and rested there.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Giezi puerum suum: Voca Sunamitidem istam. Qui cum vocasset eam, et illa stetisset coram eo,
verses.english: And he said to Gehazi, his servant: “Call this Shunammite woman.” And when he had called her, and she stood before him,

verses.latin: ait ad puerum: Quid vis ut faciam ei? Respondit Giezi: Nulla habet filium, et vir ejus senex est.
verses.english: Elisha said to his servant: “What do you want me to do for her?” Gehazi responded: “Indeed, she has no son, and her husband is old.”

verses.latin: Præcepit ergo: Voca eam. Cumque vocasset eam, stetit in ostio.
verses.english: So he commanded: “Call her.” And when he had called her, she stood in the doorway.

verses.latin: Et ait ad eam: In tempore isto, et in hac eadem hora, habebis in utero filium. At illa respondit: Noli, mi domine, vir Dei, noli mentiri ancillæ tuæ.
verses.english: And he said to her: “At this time next year, you will hold a son in your womb.” But she responded: “No, my lord, man of God, do not deceive your handmaid.”

verses.latin: Concepit ergo mulier, et peperit filium in tempore illo, et in eadem hora, quam dixerat Eliseus.
verses.english: So the woman conceived and bore a son at that very time, and at the same hour, as Elisha had said.

verses.latin: Crevitque puer. Et cum esset aliquando, et exisset ad patrem suum ad messores,
verses.english: And the boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father among the reapers in the field.

verses.latin: ait ad patrem suum: Caput meum dolet, caput meum dolet. Qui ait puero: Tollite eum, et ducite ad matrem suam.
verses.english: He said to his father: “My head hurts, my head hurts!” And his father said to a servant: “Take him and bring him to his mother.”

verses.latin: Qui cum tulisset, et ad matrem suam pertulisset, sedit super genua ejus usque ad meridiem, et mortuus est.
verses.english: And when the servant had taken him and brought him to his mother, the boy sat on her knees until midday, and then he died.

verses.latin: At illa cum ascendisset, et posuisset eum super lectulum viri Dei, clausit ostium, et egressa est.
verses.english: But she went up and laid him upon the bed of the man of God, shut the door, and went out.

verses.latin: Et vocavit virum suum, dicens: Mitte ad me unum de pueris, et unam ex asinis, ut concurram usque ad virum Dei, et revertar.
verses.english: And she called her husband, saying: “Send me one of the servants and one of the donkeys, so that I may quickly go to the man of God and return.”

verses.latin: Qui ait: Quam ob causam vadis ad eum? non est kalendæ, neque sabbatum. Illa respondit: Vale.
verses.english: He said: “For what reason are you going to him? It is not the new moon, nor the Sabbath.” These were the customary times people visited prophets. She responded: “It is well.”

verses.latin: Stravitque asinam, et sedit super eam: et dixit puero suo: Mina, et propera: non mihi loquaris, nisi dixero tibi.
verses.english: So she saddled the donkey and sat upon it. And she said to her servant: “Drive fast and hurry. Do not speak to me unless I tell you.”

verses.latin: Abiit ergo, et venit ad virum Dei in monte Carmeli: cumque vidisset eam vir Dei e contra, ait ad Giezi puerum suum: Ecce Sunamitis illa.
verses.english: So she went, and came to the man of God on Mount Carmel. And when the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to Gehazi, his servant: “Behold, there is that Shunammite woman!”

verses.latin: Vade obviam ei, et dic: Rectene se habet? Rectene se habet vir tuus? Rectene se habet filius tuus? Et illa respondit: Recte.
verses.english: “Go to meet her and ask: ‘Is all well? Is your husband well? Is your son well?’” And she responded: “All is well.”

verses.latin: Cumque venisset ad virum Dei in montem, apprehendit pedes ejus. Et accessit Giezi ut pelleret eam. Et ait vir Dei: Dimitte illam: anima enim ejus in amaritudine est, et Dominus celavit a me, et non indicavit mihi.
verses.english: But when she came to the man of God on the mountain, she took hold of his feet. And Gehazi came near to push her away. But the man of God said: “Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness. The Lord has hidden it from me and has not revealed it to me.”

verses.latin: Et illa dixit: Numquid petii filium de domino meo? numquid non dixi tibi: Ne illuderes mihi?
verses.english: And she said: “Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say to you: ‘Do not deceive me?’”

verses.latin: Et ait Giezi: Accinge lumbos tuos, et tolle baculum meum in manu tua, et vade: si occurreris homini, non salutes eum: et si te salutaverit quispiam, non respondeas illi: et pone baculum meum super faciem pueri.
verses.english: And Elisha said to Gehazi: “Gird up your loins and prepare for urgent travel. Take my staff in your hand and go. If you meet anyone, do not greet him. And if anyone greets you, do not answer him. Lay my staff upon the face of the boy.”

verses.latin: Dixitque mater pueri: Vivit Dominus, et vivit anima tua, non dimittam te. Surrexit igitur, et abiit cum ea.
verses.english: And the mother of the boy said: “As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So he arose and went with her.

verses.latin: At Giezi præcesserat eos, et posuerat baculum super faciem pueri, et non erat vox, neque sensus: reversusque est, et occurrit illi, et nuntiavit ei, dicens: Non est experrectus puer.
verses.english: But Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had laid the staff upon the face of the boy. And there was no voice, nor any sign of life. So he returned and met Elisha, and announced to him, saying: “The boy has not awoken.”

verses.latin: Ingressus est ergo Eliseus coenaculum, et ecce puer mortuus jacebat in lectulo ejus.
verses.english: So Elisha went into the upper room, and behold, the dead boy lay upon his own bed.

verses.latin: Ingressusque clausit ostium super se, et super puerum, et oravit ad Dominum.
verses.english: And having entered, he shut the door upon himself and upon the boy, and prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ascendit, et incubuit super puerum: posuitque os suum super os ejus, et oculos suos super oculos ejus, et manus suas super manus ejus: et extendit se super eum, et calefacta est caro pueri.
verses.english: Then he went up and lay upon the boy. He put his mouth upon his mouth, and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands. And he stretched himself upon him, and the flesh of the boy grew warm.

verses.latin: Et reversus est, et deambulavit per domum semel intrinsecus, et ascendit: extenditque se super eum: et oscitavit puer septies, et aperuit oculos.
verses.english: And he turned away and walked through the house once within, and then went up again. He stretched himself upon him, and the boy sneezed seven times, and then opened his eyes.

verses.latin: Et vocavit Giezi, et dixit ei: Voca Sunamitidem istam. Quæ cum vocasset eam, et ingressa esset ad eum, ait: Tolle filium tuum.
verses.english: And he called Gehazi, and said to him: “Call this Shunammite woman.” And when he had called her, and she had come in to him, Elisha said: “Take your son.”

verses.latin: Venit illa, et cecidit ad pedes ejus, et adoravit in terram: tulitque filium suum, et egressa est.
verses.english: She came, and fell at his feet, and bowed deeply in reverence towards the ground. Then she took her son and went out.

verses.latin: Eliseus autem reversus est in Galgala. Famis autem erat in terra, et filii prophetarum sedebant coram eo: dixitque uni de servis suis: Pone ollam grandem, et coque pulmentum filiis prophetarum.
verses.english: Now Elisha returned to Gilgal. There was a famine in the land, and the community of prophets were sitting before him. And he said to one of his servants: “Put on the large pot and cook stew for the community of prophets.”

verses.latin: Egressus est autem unus in agrum ut colligeret herbas agrestes: invenitque quasi vitim silvestrem, et collegit ex ea colocynthidas agrestes, et implevit pallium suum: et reversus concidit in ollam pulmenti: nesciebant enim quid esset.
verses.english: But one went out into the field to gather wild herbs. He found something like a wild vine and gathered wild gourds from it, filling his cloak. And when he returned, he cut them into the pot of stew, for they did not know what it was. These gourds were poisonous.

verses.latin: Et effuderunt sociis suis ad comedendum. Cumque comedissent de pulmento illo, clamaverunt dicentes: Mors in olla, vir Dei, et non potuerunt comedere.
verses.english: And they poured it out for their companions to eat. But when they had eaten of that stew, they cried out, saying: “Death is in the pot, O man of God!” And they could not eat it.

verses.latin: Mulier quaedam de uxoribus prophetarum clamavit ad Eliseum, dicens: Servus tuus vir meus mortuus est, et tu nosti quia servus tuus fuit timens Dominum: et ecce creditor venit ut tollat duos filios meos ad serviendum sibi.
verses.english: A certain woman, one of the wives of the prophets, cried out to Elisha, saying, "Your servant, my husband, has died, and you know that your servant truly feared the Lord. Now, look, a creditor has come to take my two sons as slaves for himself to settle the debt."

verses.latin: Et ait ad eam Eliseus: Quid vis ut faciam tibi? dic mihi, quid habes in domo tua? Illa respondit: Non habeo ancillae tuae quicquam in domo, nisi olei oram.
verses.english: Then Elisha said to her, "What do you want me to do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?" She answered, "Your maidservant has nothing at all in the house, except a single small jar of oil."

verses.latin: Qui ait: Vade, et pete mutuo ab omnibus vicinis tuis vasa vacua non pauca.
verses.english: He said, "Go now and borrow empty vessels from all your neighbors. Make sure there are not just a few of them, but many."

verses.latin: Et ingredere, et claude ostium tuum, et filiorum tuorum: et funde de oleo in universa vasa haec: et cum plena fuerint, tolles.
verses.english: Then, go inside and shut the door behind you and your sons. Pour the oil from your jar into all these borrowed vessels. When they are full, set them aside."

verses.latin: Igitur abiit mulier, et clausit ostium super se, et super filios suos: illi afferebant vasa, et illa fundebat.
verses.english: So the woman went away and shut the door behind herself and her sons. They brought her the vessels, and she continued to pour the oil.

verses.latin: Cumque plena essent vasa, dixit ad filium suum: Affer mihi vas aliud. Qui respondit: Non est vas ultra. Et stetit oleum.
verses.english: When all the vessels were full, she said to her son, "Bring me another vessel." He responded, "There isn't another vessel left." And then the oil stopped flowing.

verses.latin: At illa venit, et indicavit homini Dei. Qui ait: Vade, et vende oleum, et redde creditori tuo: tu autem, et filii tui, vivite de reliquo.
verses.english: Then she went and told the man of God what had happened. He said, "Go now, sell the oil, and pay your creditor. After that, you and your sons can live on the rest of the money."

verses.latin: Factum est autem quadam die, ut transiret Eliseus per Sunam: erat autem ibi mulier magna, quae comedit panem. Et cum frequenter transiret, devertebat ad eam ut comederet panem.
verses.english: It came to pass one day that Elisha was passing through Shunem. There was a prominent woman there who urged him to eat bread. And whenever he passed by frequently, he would turn aside to her house to eat bread.

verses.latin: Quae dixit ad virum suum: Video quia vir Dei est iste, sanctus, qui transit per nos frequenter.
verses.english: She said to her husband, "Look, I perceive that this man who passes by us so often is a holy man of God."

verses.latin: Faciamus ei coenaculum parvum, et ponamus ei in eo lectulum, et mensam, et sellam, et candelabrum, ut cum venerit ad nos, maneat ibi.
verses.english: "Let us make a small room for him on the roof, and put a bed in it for him, and a table, and a chair, and a lampstand. Then, whenever he comes to us, he can stay there."

verses.latin: Factum est igitur quadam die, ut venisset Eliseus, et diverteret ad coenaculum, et requiesceret ibi.
verses.english: So it came to pass one day that Elisha came, turned aside to the room on the roof, and rested there.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Giezi puerum suum: Voca Sunamitidem istam. Qui cum vocasset eam, et illa stetisset coram eo,
verses.english: He said to Gehazi, his servant, "Call this Shunammite woman." When Gehazi had called her, and she stood before Elisha,

verses.latin: Dixit ad eum: Dic ei: Ecce sollicita es absque omni sollicitudine pro nobis: quid vis ut faciam tibi? numquid habes opus, et loquar regi, sive principi militiae? Quae respondit: In medio populi mei habito.
verses.english: Elisha said to Gehazi, "Tell her: 'Behold, you have gone to great trouble for us with all your hospitality. What do you want me to do for you in return? Do you have any request you want me to speak to the king about, or to the commander of the army?'" She responded, "I live among my own people; I am content with my position in life and have no need of royal connections."

verses.latin: Et ait: Quid ergo vult mihi fieri? Dixitque Giezi: Non habet filium, et vir ejus senex est.
verses.english: Elisha then said, "What then can be done for her?" And Gehazi answered, "She has no son, and her husband is old."

verses.latin: Jussit ergo vocari eam. Cumque vocata fuisset, et stetisset in foribus, dixit:
verses.english: So he commanded that she be called. When she had been called and stood in the doorway, Elisha said,

verses.latin: In tempore isto, et in hac eadem hora, quando vita recurrit, habebis in utero filium. At illa respondit: Noli, mi domine, vir Dei, noli mentiri ancillae tuae.
verses.english: "At this same time next year, when life returns in its cycle, you will be holding a son in your arms." But she responded, "No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your maidservant about such a hope."

verses.latin: Et concepisset mulier, et peperit filium in tempore illo, et in eadem hora, qua dixerat Eliseus.
verses.english: And indeed, the woman conceived and gave birth to a son at that very time, at the exact hour Elisha had told her.

verses.latin: Crevit ergo puer. Et cum esset aliquando, ut exiret ad patrem suum ad messores,
verses.english: So the boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father among the reapers in the field.

verses.latin: Ait patri suo: Caput meum dolet, caput meum dolet. At ille dixit puero: Tolle eum, et duc ad matrem suam.
verses.english: He said to his father, "My head hurts, my head hurts!" So his father said to a servant, "Carry him and take him to his mother."

verses.latin: Qui cum tulisset, et duxisset ad matrem suam, posuit eum super genua sua usque ad meridiem, et mortuus est.
verses.english: When the servant had carried him and brought him to his mother, she laid him on her lap until noon, and then he died.

verses.latin: At illa cum ascendisset, et posuisset eum super lectulum hominis Dei, clausit ostium, et egressa abiit.
verses.english: But she went up to the room on the roof and laid him on the bed of the man of God. Then she shut the door and went out.

verses.latin: Et vocavit virum suum, dicens: Mitte ad me unum de pueris, et asinam, ut curram usque ad hominem Dei, et revertar.
verses.english: She called her husband, saying, "Send me one of the young men and a donkey, so I can ride quickly to the man of God and return."

verses.latin: Qui dixit ei: Quam ob causam vadis ad eum? non est calendae, neque sabbatum. Illa respondit: Bene est.
verses.english: Her husband said to her, "Why are you going to him today? It is not the New Moon festival, nor is it the Sabbath day, when people typically seek out prophets." She responded, "All is well," keeping her son's death a secret.

verses.latin: Stravit ergo asinam, et præcepit puero suo: Mina, et propera: non mihi loqui cessaveris, nisi cum dixero tibi.
verses.english: So she saddled the donkey and instructed her servant, "Drive steadily and hurry. Do not stop speaking to me on the way unless I tell you to."

verses.latin: Igitur profecta est, et venit ad virum Dei in montem Carmel. Cumque vidisset eam homo Dei e contra, ait ad Giezi puerum suum: Ecce Sunamitis illa.
verses.english: So she set out and came to the man of God on Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her coming from a distance, he said to Gehazi, his servant, "Look, there is that Shunammite woman."

verses.latin: Vade ergo obviam ei, et dic: Rectene agis tu? rectene agit vir tuus? rectene se habet filius? Illa respondit: Recte.
verses.english: "Therefore, go meet her and ask: 'Are you well? Is your husband well? Is the boy well?'" She responded, "All is well."

verses.latin: Cumque venisset ad virum Dei in montem, apprehendit pedes ejus. Et accessit Giezi ut pelleret eam. Et ait homo Dei: Dimitte illam: anima enim ejus in amaritudine est, et Dominus celavit a me, et non indicavit mihi.
verses.english: When she came to the man of God on the mountain, she grasped his feet. And Gehazi came near to push her away. But the man of God said, "Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness and anguish, and the Lord has hidden it from me and not revealed it to me."

verses.latin: Et illa ait: Numquid petii filium de domino meo? numquid non dixi tibi: Noli me seducere?
verses.english: And she said, "Did I ask my lord for a son? Did I not say to you, 'Do not deceive me with false hope' (by promising a son)?"

verses.latin: Et ait Giezi: Accinge lumbos tuos, et tolle baculum meum in manu tua, et vade: si quemcumque occurreris, non salutes eum: et si te aliquis salutaverit, non respondeas illi: et pones baculum meum super faciem pueri.
verses.english: Then Elisha said to Gehazi, "Gird up your loins and take my staff in your hand. Go quickly! If you meet anyone on the way, do not greet them with conversation, and if anyone greets you, do not answer them. Then, place my staff on the boy's face."

verses.latin: Dixitque mater pueri: Vivit Dominus, et vivit anima tua, non dimittam te. Surrexit ergo, et abiit cum ea.
verses.english: But the boy's mother said, "As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you and go without you." So Elisha rose and went with her.

verses.latin: Giezi autem præcesserat eos, et posuerat baculum super faciem pueri, et non fuit vox, neque sensus: reversusque est, et occurrit illi, et nuntiavit ei, dicens: Non surrexit puer.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had placed the staff on the boy's face. But there was no voice, and no sign of life or consciousness. So he returned to meet Elisha and reported to him, saying, "The boy has not awakened."

verses.latin: Ingressus est ergo Eliseus cenaculum: et ecce puer mortuus jacebat in lectulo ejus.
verses.english: Then Elisha entered the room on the roof, and behold, the dead boy was lying on his bed.

verses.latin: Clauso igitur ostio, egressus foras, oravit ad Dominum.
verses.english: So he went out, closed the door behind him, and prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ascendit, et incubuit super puerum: et posuit os suum super os ejus, et oculos suos super oculos ejus, et manus suas super manus ejus: et curvatus est super puerum: et calefacta est caro pueri.
verses.english: Then he went up onto the bed and lay stretched out over the boy. He put his mouth on the boy's mouth, his eyes on the boy's eyes, and his hands on the boy's hands. As he remained bowed over the boy, the boy's flesh grew warm.

verses.latin: Et reversus est, et deambulabat in domo semel atque iterum: et ascendit, et incubuit super eum: et oscitavit puer septem vicibus, et aperuit oculos.
verses.english: Then Elisha returned and walked around the house once or twice. After that, he went up again and stretched out over him. The boy then sneezed seven times, and he opened his eyes.

verses.latin: Et vocavit Giezi, et dixit ei: Voca Sunamitidem istam. Quae vocata introivit ad eum. Qui ait: Tolle filium tuum.
verses.english: Elisha called Gehazi and said to him, "Call that Shunammite woman." So she was called and came in to him. Elisha said, "Take up your son."

verses.latin: Venit illa, et corruit ad pedes ejus, et adoravit in terra: et tulit filium suum, et egressa est.
verses.english: She came, fell at his feet, and prostrated herself on the ground in worship and profound gratitude. Then she took up her son and went out.

verses.latin: Eliseus autem reversus est in Galgala. Fames autem erat in terra, et filii prophetarum manebant coram eo: dixitque uni de servis suis: Pone ollam grandem, et coque pulmentum filiis prophetarum.
verses.english: Elisha returned to Gilgal, as there was a severe famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting before him for instruction. He said to one of his servants, "Put a large pot on, and boil some stew for the sons of the prophets."

verses.latin: Et egressus est unus in agrum ad colligendas herbas, invenitque herbam agrestem, et ligavit de ea, quasi siliquas agras, et implevit pallium suum, et reversus concidit in ollam pulmenti, nescientibus cunctis.
verses.english: Then one of them went out into the field to gather herbs. He found a wild plant and gathered from it wild gourds, filling his cloak. He returned and cut them into the pot of stew, without anyone knowing what they were.

verses.latin: Et effudit in viros, ut comederent. Cumque comedissent de pulmento, clamaverunt dicentes: Mors in olla, vir Dei, et non potuerunt comedere.
verses.english: When the stew was poured out for the men to eat, as they ate, they cried out, saying, "There is death in the pot, O man of God!" And they could not eat it.

verses.latin: Naaman vero princeps militiae regis Syriae, vir dives et nobilis, et potentissimus, sed leprosus.
verses.english: Naaman, the commander of the Syrian army, was a very rich, noble, and powerful man. However, he was a leper.

verses.latin: Fuerant quippe praedatores egressi de Syria, et captivam duxerant de terra Israel puellam parvulam, quae stabat in conspectu uxoris Naaman.
verses.english: Syrian raiders had previously gone out into Israel, and they had captured a young girl. This girl was now serving Naaman’s wife.

verses.latin: Quae ait ad dominam suam: Utinam fuisset dominus meus ad prophetam qui est in Samaria: profecto sanasset eum a lepra quam habet.
verses.english: The young girl said to her mistress, “If only my master Naaman would go to the prophet who lives in Samaria, he would certainly be cured of his leprosy.”

verses.latin: Igitur ingressus Naaman ad dominum suum, nuntiavit ei dicens: Sic et sic locuta est puella de terra Israel.
verses.english: Naaman then went to his king and reported what the girl from the land of Israel had said.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei rex Syriae: Vade, et veni: et ego mittam litteras ad regem Israel. Et profectus est, sumens secum decem talenta argenti, et sex millia siclos auri, et sex vestimenta mutatoria.
verses.english: The king of Syria told Naaman, “Go now, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel.” So Naaman departed, taking with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and six changes of fine clothing as gifts.

verses.latin: Et attulit litteras ad regem Israel, in haec verba: Cum acceperis igitur litteras has, scito me misisse ad te servum meum Naaman, ut cures eum a lepra sua.
verses.english: He brought the letter to the king of Israel. The letter read: “When you receive this letter, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you so that you may cure him of his leprosy.”

verses.latin: Cumque legisset rex Israel litteras, scidit vestimenta sua, et ait: Numquid Deus sum, ut occidere possim et vivificare, ut hic mittat ad me hominem, et curem eum a lepra? Animadvertite, et videte quod occasiones quaerat adversum me.
verses.english: When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes and exclaimed, “Am I God, able to kill and to give life, that this man sends someone to me to be cured of leprosy? This is obviously a pretext; he is looking for a reason to attack me.”

verses.latin: Cum audisset autem Eliseus vir Dei, scidisse regem Israel vestimenta sua, misit ad eum, dicens: Quare scidisti vestimenta tua? veniat ad me, et sciat esse prophetam in Israel.
verses.english: However, when Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, saying: “Why have you torn your clothes? Let Naaman come to me, and he will know that there is a true prophet in Israel.”

verses.latin: Venit ergo Naaman cum equis et curribus, et stetit ad ostium domus Elisei.
verses.english: So Naaman came with his horses and chariots and stood at the entrance of Elisha’s house.

verses.latin: Misitque ad eum Eliseus nuntium, dicens: Vade, et lavare septies in Jordane, et recipiet sanitatem caro tua, atque mundaberis.
verses.english: Elisha sent a messenger out to Naaman, telling him, “Go and wash yourself seven times in the Jordan River. Your flesh will be restored, and you will be clean.”

verses.latin: Iratus Naaman recedebat, dicens: Putabam quod egrederetur ad me, et stans invocaret nomen Domini Dei sui, et tangeret manu sua locum leprae, et curaret me.
verses.english: Naaman departed in anger, saying, “I thought he would come out to me personally, and stand, and call on the name of the Lord his God, and wave his hand over the place of my leprosy, and cure me.”

verses.latin: Numquid non meliores sunt Abana et Pharphar, fluvii Damasci, omnibus aquis Israel, ut laver in eis, et mundabor? Cumque se convertisset, et abiret indignans,
verses.english: He continued, “Are not the rivers of Damascus, Abana and Pharphar, better than all the waters of Israel? Could I not wash in them and be clean?” He then turned and went away in a rage.

verses.latin: accesserunt ad eum servi sui, et locuti sunt ei: Pater, etiamsi rem difficilem jussisset te propheta, certe facere debueras: quanto magis quia nunc dixit tibi: Lavare, et mundaberis?
verses.english: His servants approached him and reasoned with him, saying, “Father, if the prophet had commanded you to do some difficult thing, you would certainly have done it. How much more, then, when he simply tells you: ‘Wash, and you will be clean’?”

verses.latin: Descendit ergo, et lavit in Jordane septies, juxta sermonem viri Dei: et reversa est caro ejus sicut caro pueri parvuli, et mundatus est.
verses.english: So Naaman went down and washed himself seven times in the Jordan, just as the man of God had instructed. His flesh was restored, becoming like the flesh of a young child, and he was completely clean.

verses.latin: Et reversus est ad virum Dei cum universo comitatu suo: et venit, et stetit coram eo, et ait: Vere scio quod non sit alius Deus in universa terra, nisi in Israel: pro obsecro ut sumas benedictionem a servo tuo.
verses.english: Then Naaman returned to the man of God with all his company. He came and stood before Elisha and declared, “Now I truly know that there is no other God in all the earth except in Israel. Therefore, I beg you, please accept a gift from your servant.”

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Vivit Dominus, in cujus conspectu sto, quia non accipiam. Et cum coactus fuisset, noluit.
verses.english: Elisha replied, “As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will accept nothing from you.” Naaman urged him, but Elisha refused.

verses.latin: Dixitque Naaman: Si jubes, detur mihi servo tuo onere duorum mularum de terra hac: non enim ultra faciet servus tuus holocaustum aut victimam diis alienis, sed Domino.
verses.english: Then Naaman said, “If you will not accept a gift, then please, let me, your servant, be given two mule-loads of this Israelite earth. For from now on, your servant will no longer offer burnt offerings or sacrifices to foreign gods, but only to the Lord.”

verses.latin: Hoc autem solum deprecator pro servo tuo, cum ingreditur rex meus templum Remmon, ut adoret ibi, et ille innitatur super manum meam, et adorem in templo Remmon, cum adoraverit ipse in eodem loco, ut ignoscat mihi Dominus famulo tuo pro hac re.
verses.english: Naaman continued, “But in this one thing, I ask the Lord to forgive your servant: when my king enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there, and he leans on my arm, and I bow down in the temple of Rimmon along with him, may the Lord forgive me, your servant, for this act of bowing.”

verses.latin: Qui dixit ei: Vade in pace. Abierat ergo ab eo aliquantulum spatii loci:
verses.english: Elisha said to him, “Go in peace.” So Naaman departed from him, and had traveled only a short distance.

verses.latin: Dixitque Giezi puer viri Dei: Ecce dominus meus pepercit Naaman huic Syro, ut non acciperet de manu ejus quae attulerat: vivit Dominus, quia curram post eum, et accipiam ab eo aliquid.
verses.english: Gehazi, the servant of Elisha the man of God, said to himself, “Look, my master has spared this Naaman the Syrian, by not accepting from his hand what he brought. As the Lord lives, I will surely run after him and get something from him!”

verses.latin: Et secutus est Giezi post Naaman. Quod cum vidisset Naaman currentem post se, desilivit de curru in occursum ejus, et ait: Recte sunt omnia?
verses.english: So Gehazi pursued Naaman. When Naaman saw him running after him, he quickly dismounted from his chariot to meet him and asked, “Is everything all right?”

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Recte sunt: dominus meus misit me, dicens: Ecce venerunt ad me modo duo adolescentes de monte Ephraim, de filiis prophetarum: da eis obsecro talentum argenti, et duas vestes mutatorias.
verses.english: Gehazi replied, “Yes, everything is well. My master sent me, saying, ‘Look, two young men, members of the prophets’ community, have just arrived from the hill country of Ephraim. Please give them a talent of silver and two changes of clothing.’”

verses.latin: Dixitque Naaman: Immo potius sume duo talenta. Et coegit eum: et ligavit duo talenta argenti in duobus saccis, et duas vestes mutatorias, et imposuit duobus pueris suis: qui et portaverunt coram eo.
verses.english: Naaman said, “By all means, take two talents!” He urged Gehazi to accept them, and then tied up two talents of silver in two bags, along with two changes of clothing. He gave them to two of his servants, who carried them ahead of Gehazi.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset ad vesperum, tulit de manu eorum, et reposuit in domo: dimisitque viros, et abierunt.
verses.english: When Gehazi reached the hill, he took the gifts from their hands and put them away in the house. Then he sent the men away, and they departed.

verses.latin: Ingressusque stetit coram domino suo. Et dixit ei Eliseus: Unde venis Giezi? Respondit: Non ivit servus tuus quoquam.
verses.english: He then went in and stood before his master. Elisha asked him, “Where have you come from, Gehazi?” He answered, “Your servant has not been anywhere.”

verses.latin: At ille: Nonne cor meum in praesenti erat, quando reversus est homo de curru suo in occursum tui? nunc igitur tempus est accipiendi pecuniae, et accipiendi vestes, et oliveta, et vineas, et oves, et boves, et servos, et ancillas?
verses.english: But Elisha replied, “Was not my spirit present when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to accept money, and to accept clothes, and olive groves, and vineyards, and sheep, and oxen, and male and female servants?” This rhetorical question from Elisha implies that it was a time of spiritual significance, not personal gain.

verses.latin: Sed et lepra Naaman adhaerebit tibi, et semini tuo usque in sempiternum. Et egressus est ab eo leprosus quasi nix.
verses.english: Elisha concluded, “Therefore, the leprosy of Naaman will cling to you and to your descendants forever.” And immediately, Gehazi departed from Elisha, a leper, white as snow.

verses.latin: Naaman autem princeps militiæ regis Syriæ erat vir magnus apud dominum suum, et honoratus, per quem dedit Dominus salutem Syriæ: erat etiam vir fortis et dives, sed leprosus.
verses.english: Naaman was the commander of the Syrian king’s army. He was a great man and highly esteemed by his master, because the Lord had granted the Syrians victory through him. He was also a powerful and wealthy man, but he was suffering from leprosy.

verses.latin: Porro latrones egressi de terra Syriæ, duxerant captivam de terra Israël puellam parvulam, quæ ministrabat uxori Naaman.
verses.english: Now some raiders had gone out from the land of Syria, and they had taken captive a young girl from the land of Israel, who now served Naaman’s wife.

verses.latin: Quæ ait ad dominam suam: Utinam fuisset dominus meus ad prophetam qui est in Samaria, profecto curasset eum a lepra quam habet.
verses.english: She said to her mistress, 'If only my master would go to the prophet who is in Samaria, he would certainly cure him of the leprosy he has.'

verses.latin: Igitur ingressus Naaman, indicavit domino suo dicens: Hæc et hæc locuta est puella de terra Israël.
verses.english: So Naaman went in and told his master, saying, 'The girl from the land of Israel said these things.'

verses.latin: Dixitque ei rex Syriæ: Vade, et veni, et ego mittam litteras ad regem Israël. Cumque abisset, tulit secum decem talenta argenti, et sex millia siclos auri, et sex mutatoria vestimentorum.
verses.english: And the king of Syria said to him, 'Go, and I will send letters to the king of Israel.' When Naaman departed, he took with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and six changes of garments.

verses.latin: Et attulit litteras ad regem Israël, dicens: Cum acceperis hujusmodi epistolam, scito quod miserim ad te servum meum Naaman, ut cures eum a lepra sua.
verses.english: And he brought the letters to the king of Israel, saying, 'When you receive this letter, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you, so that you may cure him of his leprosy.'

verses.latin: Cumque legisset rex Israël litteras, scidit vestimenta sua, et ait: Numquid Deus sum, ut occidere possim et vivificare, quia iste mittit ad me ut curem hominem a lepra sua? animadvertite, et videte quod occasiones quærat adversum me.
verses.english: When the king of Israel read the letters, he tore his clothes in grief and alarm, and said, 'Am I God, that I can kill and make alive, that this man sends to me to cure a person of his leprosy? Observe and see that he is seeking an opportunity for conflict against me.'

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset Eliseus vir Dei, scidisse videlicet regem Israël vestimenta sua, misit ad eum dicens: Quare scidisti vestimenta tua? veniat ad me, et sciat esse prophetam in Israël.
verses.english: When Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, saying, 'Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel, a man of God who can intercede.'

verses.latin: Venit ergo Naaman cum equis et curribus, et stetit ad ostium domus Elisæi.
verses.english: So Naaman came with his horses and chariots, and he stopped at the door of Elisha’s house.

verses.latin: Misitque ad eum Eliseus nuntium, dicens: Vade, et lavare septies in Jordane, et recipiet sanitatem caro tua, atque mundaberis.
verses.english: And Elisha sent a messenger to him, saying, 'Go, and wash seven times in the Jordan River, and your flesh will be restored to health, and you will be clean from your leprosy.'

verses.latin: Iratus Naaman recedebat, dicens: Putabam quod egrederetur ad me, et stans invocaret nomen Domini Dei sui, et tangeret manu sua locum lepræ, et curaret me.
verses.english: Naaman departed in anger, saying, 'I thought that he would surely come out to me, and stand and call on the name of the Lord his God, and wave his hand over the place of the leprosy, and cure me.'

verses.latin: Numquid non meliores sunt Abana et Pharphar fluvii Damasci, omnibus aquis Israël, ut laven in eis, et mundabor? Cumque se convertisset, et abiret indignans,
verses.english: 'Are not the rivers of Damascus, Abana and Pharpar, better than all the waters of Israel, that I might wash in them and be clean?' And when he had turned away and was going off in indignation, his servants approached him.

verses.latin: accesserunt ad eum servi sui, et locuti sunt ei: Pater, etiamsi duram rem dixisset tibi propheta, certe facere debueras: quanto magis quia nunc dixit tibi: Lavare, et mundaberis?
verses.english: His servants approached him and spoke to him, saying, 'My father, even if the prophet had told you to do something difficult, you would surely have done it. How much more now that he has said to you, ‘Wash, and you will be clean’?'

verses.latin: Descendit igitur, et lavit in Jordane septies juxta sermonem viri Dei: et reversa est caro ejus sicut caro pueri parvuli, et mundatus est.
verses.english: So he went down and washed seven times in the Jordan, according to the word of the man of God. And his flesh was restored like the flesh of a little child, and he was made clean.

verses.latin: Reversusque ad virum Dei cum universo comitatu suo, venit et stetit coram eo, et ait: Vere scio quia non est alius Deus in universa terra, nisi tantum in Israël: obsecro ergo ut sumas benedictionem a servo tuo.
verses.english: And he returned to the man of God with all his company. He came and stood before him, and said, 'Now I truly know that there is no other God in all the earth, except only in Israel. Therefore, I beg you to accept a gift from your servant.'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Vivit Dominus, in cujus conspectu sto, quia non accipiam. Et cum coactus fuisset, noluit.
verses.english: Elisha answered, 'As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will not accept it.' And though Naaman urged him, he refused to take the gift.

verses.latin: Dixitque Naaman: Obsecro igitur, ut detur servo tuo duo onerum mularum terra: non enim faciet ultra servus tuus holocaustum aut victimam diis alienis, nisi Domino.
verses.english: Naaman then said, 'If you will not accept a gift, then please, let two mule-loads of earth be given to your servant. For your servant will no longer offer burnt offering or sacrifice to other gods, but only to the Lord, the one true God.'

verses.latin: Hoc autem solum deprecor a Domino, ut cum ingreditur rex meus templum Remmon ut adoret, et ille innitatur super manum meam, et adorem in templo Remmon, adorante illo in eodem loco, ut ignoscat mihi Dominus servo tuo pro hac re.
verses.english: But for this one thing alone I pray to the Lord, that when my king enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there, and he leans on my arm, and I bow myself in the temple of Rimmon while he worships in that place — may the Lord forgive your servant for this action, understanding that it is out of duty to my king, not true worship of an idol.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei: Vade in pace. Abierat ergo modicum spatii de eo.
verses.english: And Elisha said to him, 'Go in peace.' So Naaman had traveled only a short distance from him.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Giezi puer viri Dei: Ecce dominus meus dimisit Naaman Syrum hunc, ne acciperet ab eo quod attulerat: vivit Dominus, quia curram post eum, et accipiam ab eo aliquid.
verses.english: But Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, said, 'Behold, my master has let this Naaman, this Syrian, depart without accepting from him what he brought. As the Lord lives, I will run after him and take something from him!'

verses.latin: Et insecutus est Giezi post Naaman. Quod cum vidisset Naaman currens in occursum suum, desiluit de curru in occursum ejus, et ait: Rectene sunt omnia?
verses.english: So Gehazi pursued Naaman. When Naaman saw him running after him, he dismounted from his chariot to meet him, and said, 'Is everything well?'

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Recte sunt. Dominus meus misit me dicens: Ecce venerunt ad me modo duo adolescentes de monte Ephraim ex filiis prophetarum: da eis obsecro talentum argenti, et vestes duas mutatorias.
verses.english: And Gehazi said, 'All is well. My master sent me, saying: Behold, just now two young men from the hill country of Ephraim, from the sons of the prophets, have come to me. Please give them a talent of silver and two changes of garments.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Naaman: Immo potius duo talenta accipe. Et coëgit eum. Ligavitque duo talenta argenti in duobus saccis, et duo mutatoria vestimentorum, et imposuit duobus pueris suis: qui et portaverunt coram eo.
verses.english: Naaman said, 'No, rather take two talents of silver!' And he urged him to take it. Then Naaman tied up two talents of silver in two bags, along with two changes of garments, and put them on two of his servants, who then carried them ahead of Gehazi.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset æstuans ad monticulum, tulit de manu eorum, et reposuit in domo: et dimisit viros, et abierunt.
verses.english: When Gehazi arrived at the hill, he took the gifts from their hands and stored them in his house. Then he sent the men away, and they departed.

verses.latin: Et ingressus stetit coram domino suo. Dixitque ei Eliseus: Unde venis, Giezi? Respondit: Non ivit servus tuus quoquam.
verses.english: And he went in and stood before his master. Elisha said to him, 'From where have you come, Gehazi?' He answered, 'Your servant went nowhere.' He was attempting to deceive his master.

verses.latin: At ille: Nonne cor meum in præsentia fuit, quando reversus est homo de curru suo in occursum tui? nunc igitur tempus est accipiendi pecuniam, et accipiendi vestes, ut emas oliveta, et vineas, et oves, et boves, et servos, et ancillas?
verses.english: But Elisha said, 'Was not my spirit present when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time now to receive money, and to receive garments, and to buy olive groves, and vineyards, and sheep, and oxen, and male servants, and female servants?'

verses.latin: Sed et lepra Naaman adhærebit tibi, et semini tuo usque in æternum. Et egressus ab eo, leprosus apparuit sicut nix.
verses.english: 'Therefore, the leprosy of Naaman will cling to you and to your descendants forever.' And Gehazi went out from his presence, a leper, as white as snow.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt filii prophetarum ad Eliseum: Ecce, locus in quo habitamus coram te, angustus est nobis.
verses.english: And the disciples of the prophets spoke to Elisha, saying, "Look, this place where we are living with you is too small for all of us."

verses.latin: Eamus usque ad Jordanem, et tollamus de lignis singuli virgam unam: ut ædificemus nobis ibi locum, in quo habitare possimus.
verses.english: They continued, "Let's go down to the Jordan River, and each of us can cut down a tree trunk or log so we can build a larger dwelling place for ourselves there."

verses.latin: Et ait Eliseus: Ite.
verses.english: And Elisha responded, "Go ahead."

verses.latin: Et dixit unus de illis: Venias ergo et tu cum servis tuis.
verses.english: Then one of the prophets' disciples said to Elisha, "Please come with us, your servants."

verses.latin: Respondit: Ego veniam. Et abiit cum eis. Cumque venissent ad Jordanem, cædebant ligna.
verses.english: Elisha replied, "I will come with you." So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they began cutting down trees and logs.

verses.latin: Cum ergo unus amputaret lignum, cecidit ferrum securis in aquam. Exclamavitque, et dixit: Heu, heu, Domine mi, et hoc mutuo habui!
verses.english: As one of them was cutting down a log, the iron axe-head flew off the handle and sank into the water. He cried out in dismay, "Oh no, my master! And I borrowed this axe!"

verses.latin: Dixit autem vir Dei: Ubi cecidit? Ille monstravit ei locum. Miscuit ergo lignum, et misit illuc: et natavit ferrum.
verses.english: The man of God, Elisha, asked, "Where did it fall?" The disciple showed him the exact spot. So Elisha cut off a small piece of wood, threw it into the water at that spot, and the iron axe-head immediately floated to the surface.

verses.latin: Rex vero Syriæ pugnabat contra Israël, et inito consilio cum servis suis, ait: In tali et tali loco ponam insidias.
verses.english: At that time, the King of Syria was at war with Israel. He consulted with his military commanders, saying, "I will set up an ambush at this particular place."

verses.latin: Misit ergo vir Dei ad regem Israël, dicens: Cave ne transeas in loco isto: quia Syriæ ibi sunt in insidiis.
verses.english: But the man of God, Elisha, sent a message to the King of Israel, warning him, "Be careful not to pass through that specific location, because the Syrian army has set an ambush there."

verses.latin: Misit itaque rex Israël ad locum, quem dixerat vir Dei, et præmonuerat eum: et præcavens, salvatus est non semel, neque bis.
verses.english: So the King of Israel sent a scouting party to the place Elisha had warned him about and had already given him a heads-up. Because he took precautions, he and his army were saved from danger, not just once or twice, but many times.

verses.latin: Conturbatumque est cor regis Syriæ super hac re: et convocatis servis suis, ait: Quare non indicatis mihi quis proditor sit nostrum ad regem Israël?
verses.english: The King of Syria became greatly disturbed by these repeated failures. He called his military commanders together and demanded, "Why aren't you telling me which one of you is betraying us to the King of Israel?"

verses.latin: Dixitque unus de servis ejus: Nequaquam, Domine mi rex, sed Eliseus propheta, qui est in Israël, narrat regi Israël omnia verba, quæ tu loqueris in conclavi cubiculi tui.
verses.english: One of his commanders answered, "It's not that at all, my Lord King. It is Elisha, the prophet in Israel, who reveals to the King of Israel every single word you speak, even those uttered in the privacy of your innermost chamber!"

verses.latin: Et ait: Ite, et videte ubi sit: ut mittam, et apprehendam eum. Nuntiatumque est ei dicentibus: Ecce in Dothan est.
verses.english: The King of Syria commanded, "Go and find out where he is, so I can send men to capture him!" His scouts reported back to him, saying, "He is in the city of Dothan."

verses.latin: Misit ergo illuc equos et currus, et robur exercitus: qui cum venissent nocte, circumdederunt civitatem.
verses.english: So the King of Syria dispatched a large army there, with horses and chariots, a truly powerful force. They marched all night and arrived at Dothan before dawn, completely surrounding the city.

verses.latin: Cumque de nocte surrexisset diluculo minister viri Dei, et egressus esset, vidit exercitum circumdantem civitatem, et equos et currus: et nuntiavit ei, dicens: Heu, heu, Domine mi, quid faciemus?
verses.english: When Elisha's personal servant woke up early and went outside, he saw a vast army, with horses and chariots, completely surrounding Dothan. He rushed back to Elisha and cried out, "Oh no, my master! What are we going to do?"

verses.latin: At ille ait: Noli timere: plures enim nobiscum sunt quam cum illis.
verses.english: But Elisha replied, "Do not be afraid; for there are more with us than there are with them!"

verses.latin: Et oravit Eliseus, et dixit: Domine, aperi oculos hujus, ut videat. Et aperuit Dominus oculos pueri, et vidit: et ecce mons plenus equorum et curruum igneorum in circuitu Elisei.
verses.english: Then Elisha prayed, "O Lord, open his eyes so that he may see!" And the Lord immediately opened the servant's eyes, and he looked up and saw, and there, on the mountains surrounding Elisha, was a magnificent sight: the mountain was completely full of horses and chariots made of fire, encircling Elisha.

verses.latin: Descenderunt autem ad eum Syri, et oravit Eliseus ad Dominum, dicens: Percute, obsecro, gentem hanc cæcitate. Et percussit eos Dominus cæcitate, juxta verbum Elisei.
verses.english: As the Syrian soldiers came down the mountain toward Elisha, Elisha prayed to the Lord, "Please strike these people with blindness!" And the Lord struck them with complete blindness, just as Elisha had prayed.

verses.latin: Dixit autem ad eos Eliseus: Non est hæc via, neque hæc est civitas: sequimini me, et ducam vos ad virum quem quæritis. Ducebat ergo eos in Samariam.
verses.english: Then Elisha said to them, "This is not the right road, and this isn't the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you are searching for." So Elisha led them, still blind, all the way to Samaria—the capital city of Israel.

verses.latin: Cumque ingressi fuissent Samariam, dixit Eliseus: Domine, aperi oculos horum, ut videant. Et aperuit Dominus oculos eorum, et viderunt: et ecce in medio Samaræ erant.
verses.english: Once they had entered Samaria, Elisha prayed, "O Lord, open the eyes of these men so they may see!" And the Lord opened their eyes, and they could see again. And they realized with shock that they were right in the middle of Samaria, surrounded by their enemies.

verses.latin: Et dixit rex Israël ad Eliseum, cum vidisset illos: Numquid percutiam eos, pater mi?
verses.english: When the King of Israel saw the Syrian army suddenly appear in the heart of his capital city, he asked Elisha, "Shall I kill them, my father?"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Non percuties: neque enim interficis quos capis gladio et arcu tuo, ut comedant et bibant, et recedant ad dominum suum.
verses.english: Elisha answered, "No, do not kill them! Would you normally kill captives you have taken with your own sword and bow? Instead, give them food and water, so they can eat and drink, and then send them back to their master, the King of Syria."

verses.latin: Paravit ergo eis cibum grandem: et comederunt, et biberunt, et dimisit eos: qui abierunt ad dominum suum. Et ultra non venerunt latrones Syriæ in terram Israël.
verses.english: So the King of Israel prepared a magnificent feast for the Syrian soldiers. They ate and drank, and then he sent them away, and they returned to their master. After this event, the Syrian raiding parties stopped invading the land of Israel for a significant time.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post hæc, ut Benadad rex Syriæ congregaret omnem exercitum suum, et ascenderet, et obsideret Samariam.
verses.english: However, sometime later, after these events, Ben-Hadad, the King of Syria, gathered his entire army, marched to Samaria, and laid siege to the city.

verses.latin: Factaque est fames magna in Samaria: et tamdiu obsessa est, donec venundaretur caput asini octoginta argenteis, et quarta pars cæmeterii columbarum quinque argenteis.
verses.english: A terrible famine gripped Samaria during the siege. The siege lasted so long that a donkey's head, normally considered unclean food, was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and even a quarter-kab of dove's droppings, a truly repulsive and desperate measure, was sold for five pieces of silver.

verses.latin: Cumque rex Israël transiret per murum, mulier vociferata est ad eum, dicens: Salva me, domine mi rex.
verses.english: As the King of Israel was walking along the city wall to inspect the defenses, a woman cried out to him desperately, "Help me, my Lord King!"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Non te salvet Dominus, unde te salvare potero? de area, an de torculari?
verses.english: The king replied, "If the Lord won't help you, how can I possibly help you? Do I have grain from the threshing floor, or wine from the winepress to give you?"

verses.latin: Dixitque ei rex: Quid tibi est? Et illa respondit: Hæc mulier dixit mihi: Da filium tuum, ut comedamus eum hodie: et filium meum comedemus cras.
verses.english: Then the king asked her, "What is your trouble?" She answered, "This woman here said to me: 'Give up your son, so we can eat him today,' and then tomorrow we will eat my son."

verses.latin: Coquimus ergo filium meum, et comedimus eum. Et dixi ei secunda die: Da filium tuum ut comedamus eum. Quæ abscondit filium suum.
verses.english: So we cooked my son, and we ate him. But the next day, when I told her, 'Now it's your turn, give us your son so we can eat him!' she hid her son.

verses.latin: Audivit ergo rex sermones mulieris, et scidit vestimenta sua: et transibat super murum: viditque omnis populus cilicio vestitum dorsum ejus intrinsecus.
verses.english: When the king heard the woman's story, he tore his clothes in a powerful display of grief and repentance. As he continued along the wall, all the people saw that beneath his royal robes, he was wearing sackcloth against his skin—a sign of deep mourning and humility before God.

verses.latin: Et ait: Hæc mihi faciat Deus, et hæc addat, si caput Elisei filii Saphat steterit super eum hodie.
verses.english: He then swore an oath, saying, "May God punish me severely and even more if I allow Elisha, the son of Shaphat, to live through this day!"

verses.latin: Eliseus autem sedebat in domo sua, et senes sedebant cum eo. Misit ergo rex virum, qui decollaret eum. Antequam veniret nuntius, dixit ipse ad senes: An vidistis quomodo filius homicidæ hujus miserit qui auferat caput meum? Videte ergo, clauso ostio, et oppressum facite eum foribus: ecce enim sonitus pedum domini ejus post eum.
verses.english: Elisha was sitting in his house at the time, and the elders of Israel were sitting with him. The King of Israel had sent an executioner to behead Elisha. But before the king's messenger arrived, Elisha, knowing by divine revelation, said to the elders, "Do you see how this son of a murderer—referring to the king—has sent someone to cut off my head? When he arrives, make sure the door is shut and hold him back with the doors! For listen, the sound of his master's footsteps—the king himself—is right behind him!"

verses.latin: Adhuc illo loquente, apparuit nuntius: et ecce rex ascendebat, et dicebat: Ecce tantum malum est a Domino: quid ultra exspectem a Domino?
verses.english: While Elisha was still speaking, the king's messenger arrived at the door. And immediately after him, the king himself ascended and began to speak, saying, "This terrible evil—this famine—comes directly from the Lord! Why should I continue to hope or wait for any help from the Lord?"

verses.latin: Et dixerunt filii prophetarum ad Eliseum: Ecce, angustus est nobis locus, in quo sedemus coram te.
verses.english: Then the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, "Look, this place where we gather and stay with you is now too small for us."

verses.latin: Itaque eamus usque ad Jordanem, et tollat unusquisque nostrum de lignis, et faciamus nobis ibi locum, in quo habitare possimus. Qui respondit: Ite.
verses.english: So let's go down to the Jordan River, and each of us will cut down a log there. Then we can build ourselves a larger place to live in. Elisha replied, "Go ahead."

verses.latin: Et dixit unus eorum: Veni ergo tu cum servis tuis. Et respondit: Ego veniam.
verses.english: But one of them said, "Please, come with your servants." He answered, "I will come."

verses.latin: Abiit ergo cum eis. Cumque venissent ad Jordanem, succiderunt ligna.
verses.english: So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.

verses.latin: Accidit autem ut cum unus incideret lignum, cecidisset ferrum securis in aquam. Exclamavitque ille, et ait: Eheu, domine mi, et hoc ipsum mutuatum est!
verses.english: But as one of them was cutting down a log, the iron head of his axe fell into the water. He cried out, "Oh no, my master! And it was borrowed!"

verses.latin: Et dixit homo Dei: Ubi cecidit? Ille ostendit ei locum. Precidetque lignum, et misit illud eo, et natavit ferrum.
verses.english: The man of God asked, "Where did it fall?" He showed him the place. So Elisha cut off a piece of wood and threw it into the water at that spot, and the axe head floated to the surface.

verses.latin: Et dixit: Tolle. Qui extendit manum suam, et tulit illud.
verses.english: Elisha said, "Pick it up." The man reached out his hand and took it.

verses.latin: Rex vero Syriæ pugnabat contra Israel, et iniit consilium cum servis suis, dicens: In loco illo et illo ponam insidias.
verses.english: Now the King of Syria was at war with Israel. He consulted with his officers, saying, "I will set up an ambush at such and such a place."

verses.latin: Misit autem homo Dei ad regem Israel, dicens: Cave ne transeas in loco illo, quia ibi Syri in insidiis sunt.
verses.english: But the man of God — Elisha — sent a message to the King of Israel, saying, "Be careful not to pass through that specific place, because the Syrians are hiding there in ambush."

verses.latin: Misit itaque rex Israel ad locum, quem dixerat ei homo Dei, et præmonuerat eum, et salvatus est ibi non semel neque bis.
verses.english: So the King of Israel sent a warning to the place which the man of God had told him about and had forewarned him against. The king saved his army there not just once or twice.

verses.latin: Conturbatumque est cor regis Syriæ propter hanc rem, et convocatis servis suis, ait: Quare non indicatis mihi, quis proditor noster sit apud regem Israel?
verses.english: The King of Syria's heart was greatly troubled by this, so he called his officers together and asked them, "Why don't you tell me which of us is betraying us to the King of Israel?"

verses.latin: Dixitque unus servorum ejus: Nequaquam, domine mi rex, sed Eliseus propheta, qui est in Israel, narrat regi Israel omnia verba, quæcumque loqueris in conclavi cubiculi tui.
verses.english: One of his officers replied, "By no means, my lord and king. It is Elisha the prophet, who is in Israel, who tells the King of Israel all the words you speak even in your secret bedchamber."

verses.latin: Qui ait illis: Ite, et videte ubi sit, ut mittam et apprehendam eum. Et nuntiaverunt ei, dicentes: Ecce in Dothan est.
verses.english: The king said to them, "Go and find out where he is, so I can send men to capture him." They reported to him, saying, "Look, he is in Dothan."

verses.latin: Misit ergo illuc equos et currus et robur exercitus: qui cum venissent nocte, circumdederunt civitatem.
verses.english: So the king sent horses and chariots and a great army there. They arrived at night and surrounded the city.

verses.latin: Et mane consurgens minister viri Dei, egressus est: et ecce exercitus circumdabat civitatem, et equos et currus: dixitque ei servus: Eheu, domine mi, quid faciemus?
verses.english: When the servant of the man of God rose early in the morning and went out, he saw an army surrounding the city with horses and chariots. The servant said to him, "Oh no, my master! What shall we do?"

verses.latin: At ille ait: Noli timere: plures enim nobiscum sunt, quam cum illis.
verses.english: But Elisha said, "Do not be afraid. For there are more with us than there are with them."

verses.latin: Et oravit Eliseus, et dixit: Domine, aperi oculos hujus, ut videat. Et aperuit Dominus oculos pueri, et vidit: et ecce mons plenus equorum et curruum igneorum in circuitu Elisei.
verses.english: Then Elisha prayed and said, "Lord, open this young man's eyes so he may see." And the Lord opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw! Behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.

verses.latin: Descenderunt autem ad eum Syri, et oravit Eliseus Dominum, dicens: Percute, obsecro, gentem hanc cæcitate. Percussitque eos Dominus cæcitate, juxta verbum Elisei.
verses.english: When the Syrians came down toward him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, saying, "Strike this nation with blindness, I beg You." And the Lord struck them with blindness, just as Elisha had requested.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos Eliseus: Non est hæc via, neque hæc est civitas: sequimini me, et ducam vos ad virum, quem quæritis. Ducebat ergo eos in Samariam.
verses.english: Then Elisha said to them, "This is not the right road, nor is this the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you seek." So he led them into Samaria, the capital of Israel.

verses.latin: Cumque pervenissent Samariam, dixit Eliseus: Domine, aperi oculos horum, ut videant. Aperuitque Dominus oculos eorum, et viderunt, et ecce erant in medio Samariæ.
verses.english: When they had entered Samaria, Elisha said, "Lord, open the eyes of these men so they may see." And the Lord opened their eyes, and they looked around. Behold, they realized they were in the middle of Samaria!

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israel ad Eliseum, videns illos: Numquid percutiam eos, pater mi?
verses.english: When the King of Israel saw them, he asked Elisha, "My father, shall I strike them down? Shall I strike them down?"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Non percuties: neque enim captivos tuos et interfectos gladio percutis: pone panem et aquam coram eis, ut comedant et bibant, et revertantur ad dominum suum.
verses.english: Elisha answered, "You must not strike them down. Do you strike down even those you have taken captive with your sword and bow? Set food and water before them, so they may eat and drink, and then return to their master, the King of Syria."

verses.latin: Paravitque eis cibum magnum, et comederunt, et biberunt, et dimisit eos. Qui abierunt ad dominum suum: et ultra non venerunt cæcatorum latrocinia in Israel.
verses.english: So the King of Israel prepared a great feast for them. After they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away. They returned to their master, and the raiding parties of the Syrians did not come into the land of Israel again.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post hæc, ut Benadad rex Syriæ congregaret omnem exercitum suum, et ascenderet, et obsideret Samariam.
verses.english: However, after this, Ben-Hadad, the King of Syria, gathered his entire army, marched up, and besieged Samaria.

verses.latin: Factaque est fames magna in Samaria: et tamdiu obsessa est, donec venundaretur caput asini octoginta argenteis, et quarta pars cacabi stercoris columbarum quinque argenteis.
verses.english: There was a great famine in Samaria. The city was under such a long siege that a donkey's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a quarter of a cab (a small measure) of dove's dung for five pieces of silver. People were desperate for any food.

verses.latin: Cumque rex Israel transiret per murum, mulier clamavit ad eum, dicens: Salva me, domine mi rex.
verses.english: As the King of Israel was walking along the city wall, a woman cried out to him, saying, "Help me, my lord and king!"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Non te salvet Dominus, unde te salvare potero? de area, an de torculari?
verses.english: He replied, "If the Lord does not save you, where can I get help for you? From the threshing floor, or from the winepress? I have no food to give."

verses.latin: Et ait ad eam rex: Quid tibi est? Quæ respondit: Mulier hæc dixit mihi: Da filium tuum, ut comedamus eum hodie, et filium meum comedemus cras.
verses.english: Then the king asked her, "What is your trouble?" She answered, "This woman said to me, 'Give up your son so we can eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.'"

verses.latin: Coquimus ergo filium meum, et comœdimus eum. Dixique ei altera die: Da filium tuum, ut comedamus eum. Quæ abscondit filium suum.
verses.english: So we cooked my son and ate him. Then I said to her the next day, 'Give up your son so we can eat him.' But she hid her son away.

verses.latin: Audiens ergo rex sermones mulieris, scidit vestimenta sua, et transibat per murum: viditque omnis populus cilicium ad carnes ejus intrinsecus.
verses.english: When the king heard the woman's words, he tore his clothes. As he walked along the wall, all the people saw that he was wearing sackcloth underneath, against his skin.

verses.latin: Et ait: Hæc mihi faciat Deus, et hæc addat, si steterit caput Elisei filii Saphat super eum hodie.
verses.english: Then the king said, "May God do so to me, and even more, if the head of Elisha, the son of Shaphat, remains on his shoulders this very day!"

verses.latin: Eliseus autem sedebat in domo sua, et senes sedebant cum eo. Misit ergo rex virum, qui decollaret eum. Antequam veniret nuntius, dixit ad senes: Numquid scitis quoniam misit filius homicidæ iste, ut auferatur caput meum? Videte ergo, cum venerit nuntius, claudite ostium, et arctate eum janua: ecce enim sonitus pedum domini ejus retro eum est.
verses.english: Now Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king had sent a messenger to behead Elisha. But before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, "Do you see that this son of a murderer has sent someone to take off my head? Look, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold it fast against him with the door bar. For indeed, the sound of his master's footsteps is right behind him!"

verses.latin: Adhuc ipso loquente eis, apparuit nuntius: et ait: Ecce tantum malum a Domino est: quid ultra expectem a Domino?
verses.english: While Elisha was still speaking with them, the messenger appeared. And the messenger said, "Look, this disaster is from the Lord! Why should I wait for the Lord any longer?"

verses.latin: Dixerunt autem filii prophetarum ad Eliseum: Ecce locus, in quo habitamus coram te, strictus est nobis.
verses.english: The sons of the prophets—that is, the disciples under Elisha's guidance—told Elisha: "Look, the place where we are staying with you is too small for us."

verses.latin: Eamus usque ad Jordanem, et tollamus de lignis singuli virgam unam, ut aedificemus nobis ibi locum ad habitandum. Qui respondit: Ite.
verses.english: "Let's go all the way to the Jordan River, and each of us will take a single log from the trees there, so we can build ourselves a new dwelling place." Elisha replied: "Go ahead."

verses.latin: Et dixit unus de illis: Veni ergo et tu cum servis tuis. Respondit: Ego veniam.
verses.english: Then one of them said, "Please, come with your servants as well." He answered: "I will come."

verses.latin: Et abiit cum eis. Cumque venissent ad Jordanem, caedebant ligna.
verses.english: So he went with them. And when they arrived at the Jordan River, they began to cut down trees.

verses.latin: Accidit autem ut unius abscidentis ligna, ferrum securis caderet in aquam. Exclamavitque ille, et ait: Eheu, Domine mi, et hoc ipsum mutuo habui.
verses.english: It happened that as one of them was cutting down a tree, the iron axe-head fell into the water. He cried out in distress and said: "Oh no, my master! And I even borrowed this axe-head."

verses.latin: Et dixit homo Dei: Ubi cecidit? At ille monstravit ei locum. Praecidit ergo lignum, et misit illuc: et natavit ferrum.
verses.english: And the man of God—that is, Elisha—asked: "Where did it fall?" The man showed him the spot. So Elisha cut off a piece of wood and threw it toward that place, and the axe-head floated to the surface.

verses.latin: Et dixit: Tolle. Porrexitque manum, et tulit.
verses.english: And Elisha said: "Pick it up." So he reached out his hand and took it.

verses.latin: Rex autem Syriae pugnabat contra Israel, et inito consilio cum servis suis, ait: In hoc et hoc loco ponam insidias.
verses.english: Now the king of Syria was making war against Israel, and after taking counsel with his servants, he said: "In such and such a place I will set an ambush."

verses.latin: Misit ergo homo Dei ad regem Israel, dicens: Cave ne transeas in loco isto: quia ibi Syri in insidiis sunt.
verses.english: Therefore, the man of God—Elisha—sent word to the king of Israel, saying: "Be careful not to pass through that specific place, because the Syrians are lying in ambush there."

verses.latin: Misitque rex Israel ad locum, quem dixerat ei homo Dei, et praemonuerat eum: et observavit se non semel, neque bis.
verses.english: And the king of Israel sent men to the place that the man of God had told him about and had warned him of. And the king of Israel took precautions there, not just once or twice.

verses.latin: Conturbatumque est cor regis Syriae pro hac re: et convocatis servis suis, ait: Quare non indicatis mihi, quis proditor noster sit apud regem Israel?
verses.english: The heart of the king of Syria was greatly troubled by this matter. He called his servants together and said: "Why don't you tell me who among us is a traitor to the king of Israel?"

verses.latin: Dixitque unus de servis ejus: Nequaquam, Domine mi rex, sed Eliseus propheta, qui est in Israel, nuntiat regi Israel omnia verba, quaecumque loqueris in conclavi tuo.
verses.english: And one of his servants said: "By no means, my lord king. It is not a traitor among us, but rather Elisha the prophet, who is in Israel, who tells the king of Israel all the words that you speak even in your private bedchamber."

verses.latin: Dixit ergo: Ite, et videte ubi sit, ut mittam, et apprehendam eum. Nuntiatumque est ei a dicentibus: Ecce in Dothan est.
