verses.english: So the king said: "Go and see where he is, so that I may send and capture him." And it was reported to him by those who said: "Look, he is in Dothan."

verses.latin: Misit ergo illuc equos et currus, et robur exercitus: qui cum nocte venissent, circumdederunt civitatem.
verses.english: Therefore, he sent horses and chariots and a strong army there. When they arrived by night, they surrounded the city.

verses.latin: Diluculo igitur consurgens minister viri Dei, et egressus vidit exercitum in gyro civitatis, et equos et currus: nuntiavitque ei, dicens: Eheu, Domine mi, quid faciemus?
verses.english: So at dawn, the servant of the man of God arose and went out, and he saw the army encircling the city, with horses and chariots. And he reported to Elisha, saying: "Oh no, my master, what shall we do?"

verses.latin: At ille respondit: Noli timere: plus enim nobiscum sunt quam cum illis.
verses.english: But Elisha answered: "Do not be afraid, for those who are with us are more numerous than those who are with them."

verses.latin: Et oravit Eliseus, et dixit: Domine, aperi oculos hujus ut videat. Et aperuit Dominus oculos pueri, et vidit: et ecce mons plenus equorum et curruum igneorum in circuitu Elisei.
verses.english: And Elisha prayed and said: "Lord, open this young man's eyes so that he may see." And the Lord opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw, and behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.

verses.latin: Descenderunt autem ad eum Syri, et oravit Eliseus Dominum, dicens: Percute, obsecro, gentem hanc caecitate. Et percussit eos caecitate, secundum verbum Elisei.
verses.english: Now as the Syrians came down toward him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, saying: "Please, strike this people with blindness." And the Lord struck them with blindness, according to Elisha's word.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos Eliseus: Non est haec via, neque haec civitas: sequimini me, et ducam vos ad virum quem quaeritis. Duxit ergo eos in Samariam.
verses.english: And Elisha said to them: "This is not the way, nor is this the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you are seeking." So he led them to Samaria.

verses.latin: Cumque introissent Samariam, dixit Eliseus: Domine, aperi oculos horum, ut videant. Aperuitque Dominus oculos eorum, et viderunt, et ecce in medio Samariae erant.
verses.english: And when they had entered Samaria, Elisha said: "Lord, open the eyes of these men so that they may see." And the Lord opened their eyes, and they saw, and behold, they were in the middle of Samaria—the capital city of Israel, deep within enemy territory.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israel ad Eliseum, videns illos: Numquid percutiam eos, pater mi?
verses.english: And the king of Israel, seeing them, said to Elisha: "Should I strike them down, my father?"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Non percuties: neque enim eos quos cepisti gladio et arcu tuo, percutis. Pone panem et aquam coram eis, ut comedant, et bibant, et revertantur ad Dominum suum.
verses.english: Elisha replied: "You shall not strike them down. For you would not strike down even those you captured with your sword and your bow in battle. Instead, set bread and water before them, so that they may eat and drink, and then return to their master."

verses.latin: Apparavitque eis cibum magnum: et comederunt, et biberunt, et dimisit eos: qui reversi sunt ad Dominum suum. Et ultra non venerunt latrones Syriae in terram Israel.
verses.english: So the king prepared a great meal for them. And they ate and drank, and he sent them away, and they returned to their master. And the raiding parties of Syria did not come into the land of Israel any more.

verses.latin: Factum est autem post haec, congregavit Benadad rex Syriae omnem exercitum suum, et ascendit, et obsedit Samariam.
verses.english: But it came to pass after these events that Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, gathered all his army, and marched up and besieged Samaria.

verses.latin: Factaque est fames magna in Samaria: et tamdiu obsessa est, donec venundaretur caput asini octoginta argenteis, et quarta pars modi stercoris columbarum quinque argenteis.
verses.english: And there was a great famine in Samaria. And it was besieged for so long that an ass's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver—an exorbitant price for an unclean animal—and a quarter of a measure of dove's dung was sold for five pieces of silver—a sign of extreme desperation.

verses.latin: Cumque rex Israel transiret per murum, mulier clamavit ad eum, dicens: Salva me, Domine mi rex.
verses.english: As the king of Israel was passing by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, saying: "Help me, my lord king!"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Dominus salvet te: unde juvare te potero? Si de area, an de torculari?
verses.english: And he said: "May the Lord help you! How can I help you? Is it from the threshing floor or from the winepress?"—implying he had no provisions from either.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei rex: Quid tibi vis? Et illa respondit: Mulier haec dixit mihi: Da filium tuum, ut comedamus eum hodie, et filium meum comedemus cras.
verses.english: And the king asked her: "What is your trouble?" And she replied: "This woman said to me: 'Give your son, so that we may eat him today, and then tomorrow we will eat my son.'"

verses.latin: Coquimus ergo filium meum, et comedimus. Dixitque mihi altera die: Da filium tuum, ut comedamus eum. Quam abscondi.
verses.english: "So we cooked my son and ate him. And the next day, I said to her: 'Give your son, so that we may eat him.' But she hid him."

verses.latin: Cum audisset rex sermones mulieris, scidit vestimenta sua, et transibat per murum: et vidit omnis populus cilicium ad carnes ejus intus.
verses.english: When the king heard the words of the woman, he tore his garments, and as he walked along the wall, all the people saw that he was wearing sackcloth underneath, next to his skin, as a sign of mourning and repentance.

verses.latin: Et ait: Haec mihi faciat Deus, et haec addat, si steterit caput Elisei filii Saphat super eum hodie.
verses.english: And he said: "May God do to me and add to it more punishment, if the head of Elisha, the son of Shaphat, remains on him this day!"—meaning he swore to execute Elisha.

verses.latin: Eliseus autem sedebat in domo sua, et senes sedebant cum eo. Misit ergo rex virum de conspectu suo. Sed antequam veniret nuntius, dixit ad senes: An vidistis quoniam misit filius homicidae iste, ut auferret caput meum? Videte ergo, cum venerit nuntius, claudite ostium, et arctate eum foribus: ecce enim sonitus pedum Domini ejus post eum est.
verses.english: Elisha, however, was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. So the king sent a man from his presence. But before the messenger could arrive, Elisha said to the elders: "Do you see that this son of a murderer—meaning the king—has sent someone to take off my head? Look, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold him back with it. For behold, the sound of his master's feet is right behind him."

verses.latin: Adhuc eo loquente, apparuit nuntius, qui veniebat ad eum: et ait: Ecce tantum malum est a Domino: quid ultra exspecto a Domino?
verses.english: While he was still speaking—Elisha, that is—the messenger who was coming to him appeared. And the messenger said: "Behold, such great evil has come from the Lord! Why should I wait any longer for the Lord's help?"

verses.latin: Dixit autem Eliseus: Audite sermonem Domini: Haec dicit Dominus: In tempore hoc cras modii duo farinae oboli erunt, et modi quatuor hordei obolo uno, in porta Samariae.
verses.english: Then Elisha, the prophet, said: 'Listen now to the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord says: Tomorrow, at this same time of day, within the gates of Samaria, the famine will be over. Then, two measures of fine flour will be sold for just one silver coin, and four measures of barley will be sold for one silver coin.'

verses.latin: Respondens autem satelles, super cujus manum rex innitebatur, homini Dei, ait: Si Dominus fecerit cataractas in caelo, numquid poterit hoc fieri? Et ille ait: Tu ipse videbis oculis tuis, et inde non comedes.
verses.english: But the royal officer, upon whose arm the king leaned (indicating his high trust and authority), answered the man of God, saying: 'Even if the Lord were to open floodgates in the sky and make food rain down, could this possibly happen?' And Elisha, the prophet, replied: 'You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not partake in the abundance that follows.'

verses.latin: Quatuor ergo viri erant leprosi juxta introitum portae, qui mutuò collocuti sunt: Quid hic nos morimur?
verses.english: Now there were four men afflicted with leprosy near the entrance of the city gate. They said to one another, 'Why are we sitting here until we die?'

verses.latin: Sive intrare voluerimus civitatem, fame moriemur; sive manserimus hic, moriendum est: venite igitur, et transfugiamus ad castra Syrorum: si pepercerint nobis, vivemus; si autem occiderint, moriemur.
verses.english: If we decide to go into the city, we will die there from starvation. If we remain here, we will also die. So come, let us desert and go over to the camp of the Syrians. If they spare our lives, we will live. But if they kill us, then we will simply die.

verses.latin: Igitur surrexerunt vesperi, ut venirent ad castra Syrorum. Cumque venissent ad principium castrorum, nullum ibidem repererunt.
verses.english: So they rose up in the evening to go to the camp of the Syrians. But when they came to the edge of the camp, they found no one there.

verses.latin: Siquidem Dominus sonitum quadrigarum et equorum, et exercitus plurimi, audiri fecerat de castris Syrorum: et mutuò dixerant: Ecce mercede conduxit adversum nos rex Israel reges Hethaeorum et Aegyptiorum, ut venirent super nos.
verses.english: For the Lord had caused the Syrian army in the camp to hear the sound of chariots and of horses, and the sound of a very large army approaching. And they had said to one another: 'Look! The king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of the Egyptians to attack us and come against us.'

verses.latin: Quamobrem surgentes et fugientes in silentio, reliquerunt tentoria sua et equos et asinos, et castra, sicuti erant: et fugerunt pro vita sua.
verses.english: Therefore, rising up, they fled in silence, abandoning their tents, their horses, their donkeys, and the entire camp, exactly as it was. They simply fled for their lives.

verses.latin: Igitur cum venissent leprosi illi usque ad principium castrorum, ingressi sunt unum tabernaculum, et comederunt, et biberunt: tuleruntque inde argentum, et aurum, et vestes, et abierunt, et absconderunt. Et rursum venerunt ad aliud tabernaculum, et inde tulerunt, et absconderunt.
verses.english: So when those lepers came to the edge of the camp, they entered one tent, and they ate and drank. They took from there silver, gold, and clothing, and they went away and hid them. Then they returned to another tent, and from there they took more things and hid them too.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt mutuò: Non recte facimus: haec dies boni nuntii est: si tacuerimus, et noluerimus nuntiare usque mane, sceleris erimus arguti. Venite, et eamus, et nuntiemus in aula regis.
verses.english: Then they said to one another: 'What we are doing is not right. This is a day of good news, and if we remain silent and do not report it until morning, we will be found guilty of a terrible crime. Come, let us go and report it in the king's palace.'

verses.latin: Igitur cum venissent ad portam civitatis, vocem miserunt, dicentes: Venimus ad castra Syrorum, et neminem ibi reperimus, nec vocem hominum, sed equos et asinos alligatos, et tentoria ut erant.
verses.english: So when they arrived at the city gate, they called out, saying: 'We came to the camp of the Syrians, and we found no one there! There was no sound of people, but only horses and donkeys tied up, and the tents just as they were left.'

verses.latin: Nuntiaverunt igitur portariis civitatis, qui statim nuntiaverunt in aula regis.
verses.english: Therefore, they reported it to the gatekeepers of the city, who immediately announced it in the king's palace.

verses.latin: Surrexitque rex nocte, et ait servis suis: Dico vobis quid fecerint nobis Syri: famem sciunt nos pati; et idcirco egressi sunt de castris, et absconderunt se in agris, dicentes: Cum egressi fuerint de civitate, capiemus eos vivos, et tunc intrabimus in civitatem.
verses.english: Then the king rose up in the night and said to his servants: 'I will tell you what the Syrians have done to us. They know that we are suffering from famine, and that is why they have left their camp and hidden themselves in the fields, thinking: When the people come out of the city looking for food, we will capture them alive, and then we will enter the city ourselves.'

verses.latin: Cui respondit unus servorum illius: Tollamus quinos equos, qui residui sunt in civitate (siquidem universa multitudo Israëlis, quae remansit in ea, his similis est: quin potius universa turba Israëlis, qui jam consumptus est), et mittamus, et videamus.
verses.english: One of his servants answered him: 'Let us take five of the remaining horses in the city. Indeed, the entire multitude of Israel that remains here is already like those who have perished (meaning, they are near death from starvation). Let us send them out, and see what is happening.'

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo duos equos, et currus, et abierunt post eos, dicentes: Ite, et videte.
verses.english: So they sent two horses and chariots (presumably carrying men), and they went out after them, saying: 'Go and see!'

verses.latin: Qui abierunt post eos usque ad Jordanem: ecce omnis via plena erat vestibus et vasis, quae projecerant Syri prae festinatione; et revertentes nuntiaverunt regi.
verses.english: They followed the Syrians all the way to the Jordan River. And behold, the entire road was full of clothing and equipment, which the Syrians had thrown away in their haste to flee. And returning, they reported it to the king.

verses.latin: Et egressus populus diripuit castra Syrorum: factique sunt modi duo farinae obolo uno, et quatuor hordei obolo uno, juxta sermonem Domini.
verses.english: Then the people went out and plundered the camp of the Syrians. And just as the Lord had declared, two measures of fine flour were sold for one silver coin, and four measures of barley were sold for one silver coin.

verses.latin: Porro rex constituerat unum de ducibus, ut esset super manum suam: quem conculcavit turba in porta, et mortuus est, juxta quod locutus fuerat homo Dei, quando venit rex ad eum.
verses.english: Now the king had appointed that very royal officer (who was his close advisor) to be in charge of the gate. But the crowd trampled him in the gateway as they rushed out, and he died, just as the man of God had prophesied when the king came to him (earlier, during the famine).

verses.latin: Evenit enim juxta sermonem hominis Dei, quo dixerat regi: Duos modios farinae obolo uno, et quatuor modios hordei obolo uno, erunt hoc tempore cras in porta Samariae.
verses.english: For it happened exactly according to the word of the man of God, who had said to the king: 'Two measures of fine flour will be sold for one silver coin, and four measures of barley will be sold for one silver coin, by this time tomorrow in the gate of Samaria.'

verses.latin: Quando et ille responderat homini Dei, dicens: Etiamsi Dominus fecerit cataractas in caelo, numquid poterit hoc fieri? Et dixerat illi: Videbis oculis tuis, et inde non comedes.
verses.english: When that officer had also responded to the man of God, saying: 'Even if the Lord were to open floodgates in the sky, could this possibly happen?' And Elisha had said to him: 'You will indeed see it with your own eyes, but you will not partake in that abundance.'

verses.latin: Et factum est ei sicut praedixerat: conculcavit enim eum populus in porta, et mortuus est.
verses.english: And it happened to him just as Elisha had foretold: for the people trampled him in the gateway, and he died there.

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum sedisset rex in domo sua, et Dominus dedisset ei requiem undique ab universis inimicis suis,
verses.english: It happened that the king was dwelling securely in his own house, and the Lord had given him rest on every side from all his enemies,

verses.latin: dixit ad Nathan prophetam: Vides quoniam ego habito in domo cedrina, et arca Dei posita est in medio pellium.
verses.english: he then said to Nathan the prophet: “Look, I am living in a house built with cedar wood, but the Ark of God, which represents the Lord's presence, is placed only inside curtains.”

verses.latin: Dixitque Nathan ad regem: Omne quod est in corde tuo vade et fac, quia Dominus tecum est.
verses.english: And Nathan said to the king: “Go and do everything that is in your heart, for the Lord is with you in this endeavor.”

verses.latin: Factum est autem in nocte illa, et ecce sermo Domini ad Nathan, dicens:
verses.english: However, it happened that in that very night, behold, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:

verses.latin: Vade et loquere ad servum meum David: Hæc dicit Dominus: Numquid tu ædificabis mihi domum ad habitandum?
verses.english: “Go and speak to My servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord: Are you the one who will build a house for Me to dwell in?’”

verses.latin: Neque enim habitavi in domo ex quo eduxi filios Israël de terra Ægypti usque in diem hanc: sed ambulavi in tabernaculo, et in tentorio.
verses.english: “For I have not lived in a permanent house from the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day; instead, I have moved about in a tabernacle, which is a portable sanctuary, and in a tent.”

verses.latin: Per omnia loca quæ transivi cum omnibus filiis Israël, numquid loquens locutus sum ad unum de tribubus Israël, cui præcepi ut pasceret populum meum Israël, dicens: Quare non ædificastis mihi domum cedrinam?
verses.english: “In all the places through which I have passed with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a word to any one of the tribes of Israel, to whom I commanded to feed My people Israel, saying: ‘Why have you not built Me a cedar house?’”

verses.latin: Et nunc hæc dices servo meo David: Hæc dicit Dominus exercituum: Ego tuli te de pascuis, sequi gregem, ut esses dux super populum meum Israël:
verses.english: “And now, you shall say this to My servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: I took you from the pastures, from following the flock, so that you would be a leader over My people Israel.’”

verses.latin: et fui tecum in omnibus ubicumque ambulasti, et interfeci universos inimicos tuos a facie tua: et feci tibi nomen grande, juxta nomen magnorum qui sunt in terra.
verses.english: “And I have been with you in all places wherever you have walked, and I have destroyed all your enemies from before you; and I have made for you a great name, like the name of the great ones who are on the earth.”

verses.latin: Et ponam locum populo meo Israël, et plantabo eum, et habitabit sub eo, et non turbabitur amplius: nec addent filii iniquitatis ut affligant eum sicut primum,
verses.english: “And I will appoint a place for My people Israel, and I will plant them there, and they will live securely under their own rule, and they will not be disturbed any longer; nor will the sons of wickedness oppress them again, as they did at the first,”

verses.latin: ex die qua dedi judices super populum meum Israël: et requiem dabo tibi ab omnibus inimicis tuis. Prædicitque tibi Dominus quod domum faciat tibi Dominus.
verses.english: “from the day that I appointed judges over My people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies. Furthermore, the Lord proclaims to you that He Himself will make a house for you—a dynasty and a lasting lineage.”

verses.latin: Cumque completi fuerint dies tui, et dormieris cum patribus tuis, suscitabo semen tuum post te, quod egredietur de utero tuo, et firmabo regnum ejus.
verses.english: “And when your days are completed, and you sleep with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you, who will come from your body, and I will establish his kingdom firmly.”

verses.latin: Ipse ædificabit domum nomini meo: et firmabo solium regni ejus usque in sempiternum.
verses.english: “He himself will build a house for My name, a temple of worship, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.”

verses.latin: Ego ero illi in patrem, et ipse erit mihi in filium: qui si inique aliquid gesserit, arguam eum in virga virorum, et in plagis filiorum hominum.
verses.english: “I will be to him a father, and he himself will be to Me a son. If he does anything wickedly, I will discipline him with the rod of men, and with the scourges of the sons of men, as a father would correct his child.”

verses.latin: Misericordiam autem meam non auferam ab eo, sicut abstuli a Saul, quem amovi a facie mea.
verses.english: “But My mercy I will not take away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I removed from My presence.”

verses.latin: Eritque fidelis domus tua, et regnum tuum usque in æternum ante faciem tuam, et thronus tuus erit firmus jugiter.
verses.english: “And your house shall be faithful, and your kingdom shall endure forever before you; and your throne shall be firm perpetually.”

verses.latin: Juxta omnia verba hæc, et juxta omnem visionem hanc, sic locutus est Nathan ad David.
verses.english: According to all these words, and according to all this vision, so Nathan spoke to David.

verses.latin: Ingressus est autem rex David, et sedit coram Domino, et dixit: Quis ego sum Domine Deus, et quæ domus mea, ut ad huc me adduxeris?
verses.english: Then King David entered and sat before the Lord, and he said: “Who am I, Lord God, and what is my house, that you have brought me to this point of favor?”

verses.latin: Sed et hoc parvum est in conspectu tuo, Domine Deus, nisi etiam locutus sis super domum servi tui in longinquum: ista est lex Adam, Domine Deus.
verses.english: “But even this is a small thing in Your sight, Lord God, unless You have also spoken concerning the house of Your servant for a long time to come; this is the law and decree of man, Lord God, that such a promise would be made.”

verses.latin: Quid ergo addere poterit David ultra quam ut loquatur tibi? Tu enim nosti servum tuum, Domine Deus.
verses.english: “Therefore, what more can David add by speaking to You? For You know Your servant, Lord God, and all his thoughts.”

verses.latin: Propter verbum tuum, et juxta cor tuum fecisti omnia magnalia hæc, ita ut notum faceres servo tuo.
verses.english: “Because of Your word, and according to Your own heart's desire, You have done all these great things, so that You might make them known to Your servant.”

verses.latin: Idcirco magnificatus es Domine Deus, quia non est similis tui, neque est Deus absque te, in omnibus quæ audivimus auribus nostris.
verses.english: “For this reason, You are magnified, Lord God, for there is none like You, nor is there any God besides You, in all that we have heard with our own ears.”

verses.latin: Quæ est autem alia gens in terra similis populo tuo Israël, quem ivisti redimere tibi in populum, et ponere tibi nomen, et facere eis magnalia et horribilia super terram, a facie gentis tuæ quam redemisti tibi ex Ægypto, gentibus et cultu eorum?
verses.english: “And what other nation on earth is like Your people Israel, whom You went to redeem for Yourself as a people, and to make a name for Yourself, and to perform great and terrible things for them on the earth, delivering them from the face of Your nation whom You redeemed for Yourself out of Egypt, from their peoples and their false worship?”

verses.latin: Et firmasti tibi populum tuum Israël in populum sempiternum: et tu Domine factus es eis in Deum.
verses.english: “And You have established Your people Israel for Yourself as a people forever; and You, O Lord, have become their God.”

verses.latin: Nunc ergo Domine Deus, sermonem quem locutus es super servum tuum et super domum ejus, suscita in sempiternum: et fac sicut locutus es.
verses.english: “Now therefore, Lord God, the word that You have spoken concerning Your servant and concerning his house, fulfill it eternally; and do as You have spoken.”

verses.latin: Ut magnificetur nomen tuum usque in sempiternum, dicentium: Dominus exercituum Deus super Israël: et domus servi tui David sit stabilita coram te.
verses.english: “So that Your name may be magnified forever, and people may say: ‘The Lord of hosts is God over Israel,’ and the house of Your servant David may be established before You.”

verses.latin: Quoniam tu Domine exercituum Deus Israël, revelasti auriculam servi tui, dicens: Domum ædificabo tibi. Propter hoc invenit servus tuus cor suum ut oraret te oratione hac.
verses.english: “For You, Lord of hosts, God of Israel, have revealed to Your servant, by whispering in his ear, saying: ‘I will build a house for you.’ Because of this, Your servant has found the courage in his heart to pray this prayer to You.”

verses.latin: Nunc ergo Domine Deus, tu es Deus, et verba tua erunt vera: tu enim locutus es ad servum tuum bona hæc.
verses.english: “Now therefore, Lord God, You are God, and Your words will be true; for You have spoken these good things to Your servant.”

verses.latin: Incipe ergo et benedic domui servi tui, ut sit in sempiternum coram te: quoniam tu Domine Deus locutus es, et benedictione tua benedicetur domus servi tui in sempiternum.
verses.english: “Begin therefore and bless the house of Your servant, so that it may be forever before You; for You, Lord God, have spoken, and with Your blessing, the house of Your servant will be blessed eternally.”
