verses.english: Hezekiah destroyed the pagan high places, shattered the idol statues, cut down the Asherah poles used for idolatry, and broke into pieces the bronze serpent that Moses had made. Even up to that time, the people of Israel had been burning incense to it, worshipping it as an idol. Hezekiah called it Nehushtan, which means 'a piece of bronze'.

verses.latin: In Domino Deo Israël speravit, et post eum non fuit similis ei de cunctis regibus Juda, sed ne illorum quidem qui ante eum fuerant.
verses.english: Hezekiah placed his trust in the Lord, the God of Israel. Among all the kings of Judah, there was no one like him, neither before him nor after him.

verses.latin: Et adhaesit Domino, et non recessit a vestigiis ejus, fecitque mandata Domini, quæ præceperat Moysi.
verses.english: He remained faithful to the Lord and did not turn away from following Him. He obeyed the commandments that the Lord had given to Moses.

verses.latin: Unde et Dominus erat cum eo, et in cunctis ad quæ procedebat, sapienter se habebat. Rebellavit quoque contra regem Assyriorum, et non servivit ei.
verses.english: Because of this, the Lord was with him, and Hezekiah prospered in everything he undertook. He also rebelled against the king of Assyria and refused to serve him any longer.

verses.latin: Ipse percussit Philisthæos usque Gazam, et omnes fines eorum, a turre custodum usque ad civitatem munitam.
verses.english: Hezekiah attacked and defeated the Philistines, conquering their territory all the way to Gaza and its borders, from the watchtowers of the small villages to the fortified cities.

verses.latin: Anno quarto regis Ezechiæ, qui erat annus septimus Osee filii Ela regis Israël, ascendit Salmanasar rex Assyriorum in Samariam, et obsedit eam:
verses.english: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah’s reign, which was also the seventh year of Hosea, the son of Elah, king of the northern kingdom of Israel, Shalmaneser, the king of Assyria, marched up against Samaria and laid siege to it.

verses.latin: et cepit eam post annos tres, anno sexto Ezechiæ, id est, anno nono Osee regis Israël, capta est Samaria.
verses.english: After three years, Shalmaneser captured Samaria. This happened in the sixth year of Hezekiah, which was the ninth year of King Hosea of the northern kingdom of Israel.

verses.latin: Et transtulit Israël in Assyrios, et posuit eos in Hala et in Habor juxta fluvium Gozan, in civitatibus Medorum:
verses.english: The Assyrian king then deported the people of Israel to Assyria. He settled them in Halah, and along the Habor River in Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes—a historical event that marked the end of the northern kingdom.

verses.latin: quia non audierunt vocem Domini Dei sui, sed prævaricati sunt pactum ejus: omnia quæ præceperat Moyses famulus Domini, non audierunt, neque fecerunt.
verses.english: This happened because they did not listen to the voice of the Lord their God. They had broken His covenant and had not obeyed any of the commandments that Moses, the servant of the Lord, had given them.

verses.latin: Anno quartodecimo regis Ezechiæ, ascendit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum ad universas civitates Juda munitas, et cepit eas.
verses.english: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah's reign, Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, marched up and attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

verses.latin: Tunc misit Ezechias rex Juda nuntios ad regem Assyriorum in Lachis, dicens: Peccavi: recede a me, et omne quod imposueris mihi, feram. Indixit itaque rex Assyriorum Ezechiæ regi Judæ trecenta talenta argenti, et triginta talenta auri.
verses.english: Then King Hezekiah of Judah sent messengers to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying: "I have sinned. Withdraw your forces from me, and whatever tribute you demand, I will pay." So the king of Assyria imposed upon King Hezekiah of Judah a payment of three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.

verses.latin: Et dedit Ezechias omne argentum quod reperiri potuit in domo Domini, et in thesauris regis.
verses.english: Hezekiah gave him all the silver that could be found in the house of the Lord and in the royal treasuries.

verses.latin: In tempore illo confregit Ezechias valvas templi Domini, et laminas auri quas ipse affixerat, et dedit regi Assyriorum.
verses.english: At that time, Hezekiah even stripped the gold from the doors of the Lord's Temple and from the doorposts that he himself had overlaid with gold, and he gave it all to the king of Assyria.

verses.latin: Misit autem rex Assyriorum Tharthan, et Rabsaris, et Rabsacen de Lachis ad regem Ezechiæ cum manu valida in Jerusalem: qui cum ascendissent, venerunt Jerusalem, et steterunt juxta aquaeductum piscinæ superioris, quæ est in via agri fullonis.
verses.english: But the king of Assyria sent his chief commander, his chief officer, and his field commander from Lachish with a large army to King Hezekiah in Jerusalem. When they had marched up, they arrived at Jerusalem and took up a position by the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, which is on the road to the Washerman's Field.

verses.latin: Vocaveruntque regem: egressus est autem ad eos Eliacim filius Helciæ, præpositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joah filius Asaph cancellarius.
verses.english: They called for the king. So Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and Joah, the son of Asaph, the recorder, went out to meet them.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos Rabsaces: Loquimini Ezechiæ: Hæc dicit rex magnus, rex Assyriorum: Quæ est ista fiducia qua niteris?
verses.english: Then the field commander spoke to them, saying: "Tell Hezekiah: 'This is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: What is this confidence in which you trust, that you think can save you?'"

verses.latin: Forsitan inisti consilium, ut præparares te ad bellum. In quo confidis, ut audes resistere?
verses.english: "You might think you have a strategy or the resources to prepare for war, but tell me, on what do you rely that you dare to defy me?"

verses.latin: An speras in baculo arundineo, et confidis super Ægyptum, super quam si innixus fuerit homo, comminutus ingreditur manum ejus, et perforat eam? Sic est Pharao rex Ægypti omnibus qui confidunt in eo.
verses.english: "Are you perhaps relying on that broken reed, Egypt, upon which if a man leans, it splinters and pierces his hand? That is exactly what Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is to all who trust in him."

verses.latin: Quod si dixeritis mihi: In Domino Deo nostro habemus fiduciam: numquid non est iste cui subvertit Ezechias excelsa et aras, et præcepit Judæ et Jerusalem: Ante aram hanc adorabitis in Jerusalem?
verses.english: "But if you say to me, 'We trust in the Lord our God,' then I ask: 'Is this not the God whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed? And Hezekiah commanded Judah and Jerusalem to worship only before this one altar in Jerusalem?'"

verses.latin: Nunc igitur transite ad dominum meum regem Assyriorum, et dabo vobis duo millia equorum, et videte an possitis ex his habere ascensores.
verses.english: "Now, therefore, make a wager with my lord, the king of Assyria. I will give you two thousand horses, if you can find enough riders for them from among your people."

verses.latin: Et quomodo potestis resistere uni principi de servis domini mei minimis? an fiduciam habes super Ægyptum propter currus et equites?
verses.english: "How then can you resist even one of my master's least significant officials? You must be relying on Egypt for chariots and horsemen, as you have no strength of your own."

verses.latin: Numquid sine Domini voluntate ascendi ad locum istum ut demolirer eum? Dominus dixit ad me: Ascende ad terram hanc, et demolire eam.
verses.english: "Furthermore, do you think I have come up against this place to destroy it without the Lord's will? No, the Lord Himself said to me: 'Go up against this land and destroy it.'"

verses.latin: Dixerunt autem Eliacim filius Helciæ, et Sobna, et Joah, Rabsaci: Loquere ad servos tuos syriace, siquidem intelligimus: et ne loquaris nobis judaice, audiente populo qui est super murum.
verses.english: Then Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah, and Shebna, and Joah said to the field commander: "Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak to us in the language of Judah while the people who are on the wall are listening, as it will demoralize them."

verses.latin: Responditque eis Rabsaces: Numquid ad dominum tuum et ad te misit me dominus meus, ut loquerer verba hæc? et non potius ad viros qui sedent super murum, ut comedant stercora sua, et bibant urinam suam vobiscum?
verses.english: But the field commander replied to them: "Has my master sent me to speak these words only to your master and to you? Is it not also to the men who are sitting on the wall, who will soon be forced to eat their own dung and drink their own urine along with you, because of the siege?"

verses.latin: Stetit itaque Rabsaces, et clamavit voce magna judaice, et ait: Audite verba regis magni, regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: So the field commander stood up and shouted in a loud voice, in the language of Judah, saying: "Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!"

verses.latin: Hæc dicit rex: Non vos decipiat Ezechias, nec enim poterit eruere vos de manu mea.
verses.english: "This is what the king says: 'Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he cannot deliver you from my hand.'"

verses.latin: Neque vobis persuadeat super Domino, dicens: Eruens liberabit nos Dominus, et non tradetur civitas hæc in manu regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: "Nor should he persuade you to rely on the Lord, saying: 'The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.'"

verses.latin: Nolite audire Ezechiam. Hæc enim dicit rex Assyriorum: Facite mecum quod vobis est utile, et egredimini ad me: et unicuique vestrum erit vinea sua, et ficus sua, et bibetis aquas de cisternis vestris,
verses.english: "Do not listen to Hezekiah. For this is what the king of Assyria says: 'Make peace with me and surrender to me. Then each of you will be able to enjoy your own vineyard and fig tree, and drink water from your own cisterns—a promise of prosperity under Assyrian rule.'"

verses.latin: donec veniam, et auferam vos ad terram quæ similis est terræ vestræ, terram frumenti et vini, terram panis et vinearum, terram oliveti et olei, ac mellis: et vivetis, et non moriemini. Nolite audire Ezechiam, qui vos decipit dicens: Dominus liberabit nos.
verses.english: "Until I come and take you away to a land like your own, a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive groves and honey. You will live there and not die. Do not listen to Hezekiah, who deceives you by saying: 'The Lord will deliver us.'"

verses.latin: Numquid liberaverunt dii gentium, unusquisque terram suam de manu regis Assyriæ?
verses.english: "Have the gods of any of the nations ever delivered their land from the hand of the king of Assyria?"

verses.latin: Ubi est deus Emath, et Arphad? ubi est deus Sepharvaim, Ana, et Ava? numquid liberaverunt Samariam de manu mea?
verses.english: "Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria from my hand?"

verses.latin: Quis est ex omnibus diis terrarum istarum, qui eruerit terram suam de manu mea, ut possit eruere Dominus Jerusalem de manu mea?
verses.english: "Which of all the gods of these lands has delivered his land from my hand, that the Lord could deliver Jerusalem from my hand?"

verses.latin: Tacuit itaque populus, et non respondit ei quicquam: siquidem præceptum regis acceperant, ut non responderent ei.
verses.english: But the people remained silent and did not answer him a single word, for the king had given a strict command: "Do not answer him."

verses.latin: Venit itaque Eliacim filius Helciæ, præpositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joah filius Asaph cancellarius, ad Ezechiam scissis vestibus, et nuntiaverunt ei verba Rabsacis.
verses.english: Then Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and Joah, the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn in an expression of grief, and reported to him the words of the field commander.

verses.latin: Anno tertio Osee filii Ela regis Israel, regnavit Ezechias filius Achaz regis Juda.
verses.english: It was during the third year that Osee, the son of Ela, ruled as king of Israel, when Ezechias, the son of Achaz, began to reign as king of Judah.

verses.latin: Viginti quinque annorum erat cum regnare cœpisset, et viginti novem annis regnavit in Jerusalem: nomen matris ejus Abi filia Zachariæ.
verses.english: Ezechias was twenty-five years old when he began his reign, and he ruled in Jerusalem for twenty-nine years. His mother’s name was Abi, the daughter of Zacharias.

verses.latin: Fecitque quod bonum erat coram Domino, juxta omnia quæ fecerat David pater ejus.
verses.english: He did what was good and pleasing in the sight of the Lord, just as his father David had done in all things.

verses.latin: Ipse delevit excelsa, et contrivit statuas, et succidit lucos, confregitque serpentem æneum quem fecerat Moyses: siquidem usque ad illud tempus filii Israel adolebant ei: et vocavit nomen ejus Nohestan.
verses.english: It was Ezechias who destroyed the high places of idolatry, broke apart the pagan statues, cut down the Asherah poles, and crushed the bronze serpent that Moses had made. The reason he did this was because, up to that very time, the children of Israel were still offering incense to it, and he named it Nohestan, meaning a mere piece of bronze.

verses.latin: In Domino Deo Israel speravit: neque post illum similis ei fuit de cunctis regibus Juda, sed neque ex his qui ante eum fuerunt.
verses.english: Ezechias placed his hope and trust in the Lord, the God of Israel. No king like him, among all the kings of Judah, arose after him, nor among those who ruled before him.

verses.latin: Et adhæsit Domino, et non recessit a vestigiis ejus, fecitque mandata ejus, quæ præceperat Moysi.
verses.english: He remained faithful to the Lord and did not turn away from His commandments. He kept all the commands that the Lord had given to Moses.

verses.latin: Et Dominus erat cum eo, et ad omnia quæ procedebat, sapienter se habebat. Rebellavit quoque contra regem Assyriorum, et non servivit ei.
verses.english: The Lord was with him, and in everything he undertook, he acted with wisdom. He even rebelled against the king of the Assyrians and refused to serve him.

verses.latin: Ipse percussit Philisthæos usque Gazam, et omnes fines eorum, a turre custodum usque ad civitatem munitam.
verses.english: It was Ezechias who struck down the Philistines, conquering all their territory from the watchtowers of their outposts all the way to the fortified cities, extending his victory even to Gaza.

verses.latin: Anno quarto regis Ezechiæ, qui erat annus septimus Osee filii Ela regis Israel, ascendit Salmanasar rex Assyriorum contra Samariam, et obsedit eam,
verses.english: In the fourth year of King Ezechias’ reign — which was also the seventh year that Osee, the son of Ela, ruled as king of Israel — Salmanasar, the king of the Assyrians, marched against Samaria and besieged the city.

verses.latin: et cepit eam post tres annos: anno sexto Ezechiæ, id est, nono anno Osee regis Israel, capta est Samaria.
verses.english: And after three years of siege, Salmanasar took the city. This occurred in the sixth year of Ezechias’ reign, which was the ninth year that Osee ruled as king of Israel, when Samaria was finally captured.

verses.latin: Et transtulit rex Assyriorum Israel in Assyrios, et posuit eos in Hala et in Habor juxta fluvium Gozan, in civitatibus Medorum:
verses.english: Then the king of Assyria deported the people of Israel into Assyria, settling them in Hala, and in Habor by the river Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.

verses.latin: quia non audierunt vocem Domini Dei sui, sed transgressi sunt pactum ejus: et omnia quæ præceperat Moyses servus Domini, non audierunt, neque fecerunt.
verses.english: This happened because they did not listen to the voice of the Lord their God. Instead, they broke His covenant and did not obey or follow any of the commandments that Moses, the servant of the Lord, had given them.

verses.latin: Anno quartodecimo regis Ezechiæ, ascendit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum ad universas civitates Juda munitas, et cepit eas.
verses.english: In the fourteenth year of King Ezechias’ reign, Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, marched against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

verses.latin: Tunc misit Ezechias rex Juda nuntios ad regem Assyriorum in Lachis, dicens: Peccavi: recede a me: et omne quod imposueris mihi, feram. Indixit itaque rex Assyriorum Ezechiæ regi Judæ trecenta talenta argenti, et triginta talenta auri.
verses.english: At that time, Ezechias, the king of Judah, sent messengers to the king of Assyria in Lachis, saying, "I have sinned. Withdraw from me, and whatever you impose on me, I will bear it." So the king of Assyria demanded from Ezechias, the king of Judah, three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.

verses.latin: Et dedit Ezechias omne argentum quod reperiri potuit in domo Domini, et in thesauris regis.
verses.english: And Ezechias gave him all the silver that could be found in the House of the Lord and in the royal treasuries.

verses.latin: In tempore illo confregit Ezechias valvas templi Domini, et laminas auri quas ipse affixerat, deditque eas regi Assyriorum.
verses.english: At that same time, Ezechias cut off the gold from the doors of the Lord’s temple and from the gold plates which he himself had affixed to them, and he gave them to the king of Assyria.

verses.latin: Misit autem rex Assyriorum Tharthan et Rabsaris et Rabsacen de Lachis ad regem Ezechiam cum manu gravi in Jerusalem: qui cum ascendissent, venerunt Jerusalem, et steterunt juxta aquaeductum piscinæ superioris, quæ est in via agri Fullonis.
verses.english: Nevertheless, the king of Assyria sent Tharthan, Rabsaris, and Rabsacen from Lachis to King Ezechias with a powerful army against Jerusalem. When they arrived, they came to Jerusalem and took up positions by the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, which is on the road to the Fuller’s Field.

verses.latin: Vocaveruntque regem: egressusque est ad eos Eliacim filius Helciæ præpositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joahe filius Asaph cancellarius.
verses.english: They called for the king, and so Eliacim, the son of Helcias, who was in charge of the palace, along with Sobna the scribe and Joahe, the son of Asaph, the recorder, went out to meet them.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos Rabsacen: Loquimini Ezechiæ: Hæc dicit rex magnus, rex Assyriorum: Quæ est ista fiducia qua niteris?
verses.english: Then Rabsacen said to them, "Speak to Ezechias: ‘This is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: What is this confidence in which you are trusting?’"

verses.latin: Forsitan inisti consilium, ut præpares te ad bellum: in quo habes fiduciam, ut audeas mihi repugnare?
verses.english: “‘Perhaps you have formed a plan to prepare yourself for war, but in what do you place your trust that you dare to defy me?’"

verses.latin: An speras in baculo arundineo et confracto Ægypto, super quem si innitatur homo, comminutus ingreditur manum ejus, et perforat eam? sic est Pharao rex Ægypti, omnibus qui confidunt in eo.
verses.english: “‘Do you truly hope and trust in Egypt, that broken reed staff, which if a man leans on it, will splinter and pierce his hand? That is exactly what Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is like to all who trust in him.’"

verses.latin: Quod si dixeritis mihi: In Domino Deo nostro habemus fiduciam: numquid non est iste, cujus excelsa et altaria abstulit Ezechias, et præcepit Judæ et Jerusalem: Ante altare hoc adorabitis in Jerusalem?
verses.english: “‘But if you say to me, "We trust in the Lord our God," is He not the very one whose high places and altars Ezechias removed? Did Ezechias not command Judah and Jerusalem saying, "You shall worship only before this single altar in Jerusalem?"’"

verses.latin: Nunc igitur sponde regi dominum meum regem Assyriorum, et dabo tibi duo millia equorum, si poteris ex te præbere ascensores eorum.
verses.english: “‘Now therefore, make a pledge to my lord, the king of Assyria, and I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able to provide riders for them from your own forces.’"

verses.latin: Et quomodo poteris resistere uni principi de servis minimis domini mei? an fiduciam habes super Ægyptum propter currus et equites?
verses.english: “‘How then can you resist even one of the least of my master’s servants? Do you truly place your trust in Egypt because of their chariots and horsemen?’"

verses.latin: Numquid sine Domino ascendi ad locum istum, ut demolirer eum? Dominus dixit mihi: Ascende ad terram hanc, et demolire eam.
verses.english: “‘Have I come up against this place to destroy it without the Lord’s approval? No! The Lord Himself said to me, "Go up against this land and destroy it."’"

verses.latin: Dixit autem Eliacim filius Helciæ, et Sobna, et Joahe, Rabsacen: Precamur te ut loquaris servis tuis syriace: siquidem intelligimus: et ne loquaris nobis judaice, audiente populo qui est super murum.
verses.english: Then Eliacim, the son of Helcias, and Sobna, and Joahe said to Rabsacen, "We beg you, please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak to us in the language of Judah while the people who are on the wall are listening."

verses.latin: Responditque eis Rabsacen: Numquid ad dominum tuum et ad te misit me dominus meus, ut loquerer sermones istos? et non potius ad viros qui sedent super murum, ut comedant stercora sua, et bibant urinam suam vobiscum?
verses.english: But Rabsacen answered them, "Has my master sent me to your master and to you alone to speak these words? Is it not rather to the men who sit on the wall, so that they may be forced to eat their own dung and drink their own urine along with you?"

verses.latin: Stetit itaque Rabsacen, et clamavit voce magna judaice, et ait: Audite sermonem regis magni, regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: So Rabsacen stood and cried out with a loud voice in the language of Judah, saying, "Hear the word of the great king, the king of Assyria!"

verses.latin: Hæc dicit rex: Non vos decipiat Ezechias, quia non poterit eripere vos de manu mea.
verses.english: “‘This is what the king says: "Do not let Ezechias deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you from my hand."’"

verses.latin: Neque vobis persuadeat super Domino, dicens: Eripuit nos Dominus, et non tradetur civitas hæc in manu regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: “‘Nor let him persuade you to trust in the Lord by saying, "The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria."’"

verses.latin: Nolite audire Ezechiam. Hæc enim dicit rex Assyriorum: Facite mecum quod vultis, et egredimini ad me: et unicuique vestrum comedite vineam suam, et ficum suam, et bibite aquas de cisternis vestris,
verses.english: “‘Do not listen to Ezechias! For this is what the king of Assyria says: "Make peace with me and come out to me. Then each of you will be able to eat from your own vine and your own fig tree, and drink water from your own cisterns.’"

verses.latin: donec veniam, et transferam vos ad terram quæ similis est terræ vestræ, terram panis et vini, terram fructuum, et oliveti, et olei, ac mellis, et vivetis, et non moriemini. Nolite audire Ezechiam, qui vos decipit, dicens: Dominus liberabit nos.
verses.english: “‘Until I come and take you away to a land that is like your own land — a land of grain and wine, a land of fruit, olive groves, olive oil, and honey. You will live there and not die. Do not listen to Ezechias, who deceives you by saying, "The Lord will deliver us."’"

verses.latin: Numquid liberaverunt dii gentium, unusquisque terram suam de manu regis Assyriorum?
verses.english: “‘Have the gods of the other nations ever delivered their own land from the hand of the king of Assyria?’"

verses.latin: Ubi est deus Emath, et Arphad? ubi est deus Sepharvaim, Ana, et Ava? numquid liberaverunt Samariam de manu mea?
verses.english: “‘Where are the gods of Emath and Arphad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Ana, and Ava? Did they deliver Samaria from my hand?’"

verses.latin: Quis est in universis diis terrarum, qui eruerit terram suam de manu mea, ut possit eruere Dominus Jerusalem de manu mea?
verses.english: “‘Which of all the gods of these lands has delivered his land from my hand, that the Lord should be able to deliver Jerusalem from my hand?’"

verses.latin: Et siluit populus, et non respondit ei verbum: siquidem præceptum regis erat, dicentis: Ne respondeatis ei.
verses.english: But the people remained silent and did not answer him a single word, because the king’s command was clear: "Do not answer him."

verses.latin: Venit ergo Eliacim filius Helciæ præpositus domus, et Sobna scriba, et Joahe filius Asaph cancellarius ad Ezechiam scissis vestibus, et nuntiaverunt ei sermones Rabsacen.
verses.english: Then Eliacim, the son of Helcias, who was in charge of the palace, and Sobna the scribe, and Joahe, the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Ezechias with their clothes torn, and they reported to him the words of Rabsacen.

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum audisset rex Ezechias, scidit vestimenta sua, et obvolutus est sacco, et intravit in domum Domini.
verses.english: When King Hezekiah heard this news, he tore his garments to show his great distress, wrapped himself in sackcloth to show his sorrow and repentance, and went into the Temple of the Lord to pray.

verses.latin: Et misit Eliachim praepositum domus, et Sobnam scribam, et seniores de sacerdotibus, opertos saccis, ad Isaiam prophetam filium Amos.
verses.english: Then King Hezekiah sent Eliakim, the steward of his palace, and Shebna the royal scribe, and the senior priests (all of them clothed in sackcloth, just as the King was, to show their shared sorrow), to the Prophet Isaiah, the son of Amoz.

verses.latin: Qui dixerunt ei: Haec dicit Ezechias: Dies tribulationis, et increpationis, et blasphemiae, dies hic est: quia venerunt filii usque ad partum, et vires non sunt parienti.
verses.english: And they delivered the message to him, saying: 'King Hezekiah says this: This is a day of tremendous anguish, of God's rebuke, and of blasphemy against the True God. It is as if a woman is in labor, and the children are ready to be born, but she has no strength left to deliver them. We are in a critical situation, but we are too weak to bring about our own rescue.'

verses.latin: Si quomodo audiat Dominus Deus tuus omnia verba Sennacherib, quem misit rex Assyriorum dominus suus ad exprobrandum Deum viventem, et arguendum sermonibus quos audivit Dominus Deus tuus: leva ergo orationem pro reliquiis quae repertae sunt.
verses.english: 'Perhaps the Lord your God will hear all the words of Sennacherib, whom the king of Assyria, his master, has sent to insult the living God, and will rebuke him for the words which the Lord your God has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayers for the small remnant that remains of us.'

verses.latin: Venerunt ergo servi regis Ezechiae ad Isaiam.
verses.english: So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eos Isaias: Haec dicite domino vestro: Haec dicit Dominus: Noli timere a facie sermonum quos audisti, quibus blasphemaverunt pueri regis Assyriorum me.
verses.english: And Isaiah said to them: 'Say this to your master: The Lord says this: Do not be afraid because of the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.'

verses.latin: Ecce ego immittam spiritum super eum, et audiet nuntium, et revertetur in terram suam, et dejiciam eum gladio in terra sua.
verses.english: 'Behold, I will put a spirit within him (a divine impulse of fear or decision), and he will hear a rumor and return to his own land. And there, in his own land, I will cause him to be struck down by the sword.'

verses.latin: Reversus est igitur Rabsaces, et invenit regem Assyriorum juxta Lobnam: pugnabat enim contra Lobnam.
verses.english: So Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah, because he had moved his forces from Lachish.

verses.latin: Audierat enim de Tharaca rege Aethiopiae dicentes: Ecce egressus est ut pugnet adversum te. Et rursum misit nuntios ad Ezechiam, dicens:
verses.english: For Sennacherib had heard a report about Tirhakah, the king of Ethiopia, that he had set out to fight against him. And so, the king of Assyria again sent messengers to King Hezekiah, saying:

verses.latin: Haec dicite Ezechiae regi Juda: Non te decipiat Deus tuus in quo habes fiduciam, dicens: Non dabitur Jerusalem in manu regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: 'Say this to Hezekiah, king of Judah: Do not let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you by saying: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.'

verses.latin: Ecce audisti omnia quae fecerunt reges Assyriorum universis terris, quomodo vastaverunt eas: et tu poteris liberari?
verses.english: 'Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other lands, how they utterly destroyed them. And do you think you can be delivered?'

verses.latin: Numquid liberaverunt dii gentium singulos, quos vastaverunt patres mei, Gozan, et Haran, et Reseph, et filios Eden, qui erant in Thelassar?
verses.english: 'Did the gods of the nations deliver those whom my fathers destroyed, like Gozan, and Haran, and Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?'

verses.latin: Ubi est rex Emath, et rex Arphad, et rex urbis Sepharvaim, Ana, et Ava?
verses.english: 'Where is the king of Hamath, and the king of Arpad, and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena, and of Ivvah?'

verses.latin: Et accepit Ezechias libros de manu nuntiorum, et legit illos, et ascendit in domum Domini, et expandit eos coram Domino:
verses.english: And Hezekiah received the letters (the written messages) from the hand of the messengers and read them. Then he went up to the Temple of the Lord and spread the letters out before the Lord.

verses.latin: et oravit in conspectu ejus, dicens: Domine Deus Israël, qui sedes super Cherubim, tu es Deus solus omnium regnorum terrae: tu fecisti caelum et terram.
verses.english: And Hezekiah prayed in His presence, saying: 'O Lord, God of Israel, Who sits enthroned above the Cherubim (representing Your divine presence), You alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth; You created the entire universe and the earth.'

verses.latin: Inclina, Domine, aurem tuam, et audi: aperi, Domine, oculos tuos, et vide: et audi omnia verba Sennacherib, qui misit ad exprobrandum Deum viventem.
verses.english: 'Incline Your ear, O Lord, and hear! Open Your eyes, O Lord, and see! And listen to all the words of Sennacherib, who has sent his messengers to insult the living God.'

verses.latin: Vere, Domine, vastaverunt reges Assyriorum gentes, et terras omnium.
verses.english: 'It is true, O Lord, that the kings of Assyria have devastated the nations and their lands, destroying all of them.'

verses.latin: Et miserunt deos eorum in ignem: non enim erant dii, sed opera manuum hominum de ligno et lapide, et perdiderunt eos.
verses.english: 'And they threw the pagan gods of those nations into the fire, for those were not truly gods, but merely the work of human hands, made of wood and stone. That is why the Assyrians were able to destroy them.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo, Domine Deus noster, salvos nos fac de manu ejus, ut sciant omnia regna terrae, quia tu es Dominus Deus solus.
verses.english: 'Now therefore, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone are the Lord God.'

verses.latin: Misit autem Isaias filius Amos ad Ezechiam, dicens: Haec dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Quae deprecatus es me super Sennacherib regem Assyriorum, audivi.
verses.english: Then Isaiah, the son of Amoz, sent a message to Hezekiah, saying: 'Thus says the Lord God of Israel: I have heard your prayer regarding Sennacherib, the king of Assyria.'

verses.latin: Iste est sermo, quem locutus est Dominus de eo: Sprevit te, et irrisit te virgo filia Sion: post te caput movit filia Jerusalem.
verses.english: 'This is the word which the Lord has spoken concerning him: The virgin daughter of Zion (Jerusalem) despises you and mocks you; the daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head behind you (in derision).'

verses.latin: Quem exprobrasti, et quem blasphemasti? contra quem exaltasti vocem, et elevasti in excelsum oculos tuos? contra Sanctum Israël.
verses.english: 'Whom have you insulted and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes so proudly to the heavens? It was against the Holy One of Israel!'

verses.latin: Per manus nuntiorum tuorum exprobrasti Domino, et dixisti: In multitudine curruum meorum ascendi excelsa montium, juga Libani: et succidi proceras cedros ejus, et electas abietes ejus, et ingrediebar usque ad terminos ejus, saltum Carmeli ejus.
verses.english: 'By the hand of your messengers, you have insulted the Lord, and you said: “With the multitude of my chariots, I have ascended the highest mountains, to the peaks of Lebanon. I have cut down its tallest cedars and its choicest fir trees. I penetrated its farthest reaches, even to its thickest forest, like the forest of Carmel.”'

verses.latin: Ego fodi, et bibi aquas alienas, et siccavi vestigio pedis mei omnes rivos aggerum.
verses.english: '“I myself have dug wells and drunk foreign waters. With the sole of my foot, I have dried up all the rivers of the besieged lands.”'

verses.latin: Numquid non audisti? a longe feci illud, ex diebus antiquis formavi illud: et nunc adduxi, et factum est in ruinam collium, et murorum munitorum: et civitates fortes redactae sunt in acervos lapidum.
verses.english: 'Have you not heard that I (God) have prepared this from long ago? From ancient days, I (God) planned it, and now I (God) have brought it to pass. It was I who decreed that fortified cities would become heaps of rubble.'

verses.latin: Et qui sederunt in illis, confusi sunt, et contremuerunt, et facti sunt sicut foenum agri, et herba pascuae, et tegumentum tectorum, quae exsiccata sunt antequam maturescant.
verses.english: 'And those who lived in those cities were put to shame and trembled with fear. They became like the grass of the field, and like the tender herb of the pasture, and like the dry grass on the rooftops, which withers before it grows tall.'

verses.latin: Habitationem tuam, et egressum tuum, et introitum tuum, et viam tuam ego praescivi.
verses.english: 'I (God) know your dwelling, and your going out, and your coming in, and your way of life. All your movements and intentions were known to Me.'

verses.latin: Insanisti in me, et superbia tua ascendit in aures meas: ponam ergo circulum in naribus tuis, et frenum in labiis tuis, et reducam te in viam per quam venisti.
verses.english: 'Because you have raged against Me, and your arrogance has reached My ears, I will put My hook in your nose and My bridle in your lips, and I will lead you back by the very way you came.'

verses.latin: Tibi autem hoc erit signum: comede hoc anno, quae sponte nascuntur: et in secundo anno pomis vescere: in anno autem tertio seminate, et metite, et plantate vineas, et comedite fructum earum.
verses.english: 'And this will be a sign to you, Hezekiah: This year, you will eat what grows of itself (from the scattered seeds of the previous harvest); and in the second year, you will eat what springs up from that. But in the third year, you will sow and reap, and plant vineyards and eat their fruit.'

verses.latin: Et adjiciet id, quod evadit de domo Juda, et reliquum est, radicem deorsum mittere, et facere fructum sursum.
verses.english: 'And the remnant that escapes from the house of Judah and remains will again take root downward and bear fruit upward.'

verses.latin: De Jerusalem quippe exibunt reliquiae, et quod salvetur de monte Sion: zelus Domini exercituum faciet hoc.
verses.english: 'For from Jerusalem will go forth a remnant, and from Mount Zion will come those who are saved. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will accomplish this.'

verses.latin: Propterea haec dicit Dominus de rege Assyriorum: Non ingredietur civitatem hanc, et non jaciet in eam telum, et non occupabit eam clypeus, et non circumdabit eam agger.
verses.english: 'Therefore, thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He will not enter this city, nor will he shoot an arrow into it, nor will he bring a shield against it, nor will he build up a siege ramp against it.'

verses.latin: In via qua venit, per eam revertetur: et civitatem hanc non ingredietur, dicit Dominus.
verses.english: 'By the way he came, by the same way he will return. And this city he will not enter, declares the Lord.'

verses.latin: Et protegam civitatem hanc, et salvabo eam propter me, et propter David servum meum.
verses.english: 'For I will protect this city and save it, for My own sake and for the sake of My servant David.'

verses.latin: Factum est igitur in nocte illa, venit angelus Domini, et percussit in castris Assyriorum centum octoginta quinque millia. Cumque mane surrexisset, vidit omnia corpora mortuorum.
verses.english: And it came to pass that very night, the Angel of the Lord went out and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand men in the camp of the Assyrians. When people rose early in the morning, they saw all the bodies of the dead.

verses.latin: Et egressus est, et abiit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum: et reversus est, et mansit in Ninive.
verses.english: So Sennacherib, king of Assyria, broke camp and departed. He returned to his land and remained in Nineveh.

verses.latin: Cumque adoraret in templo Nesroch dei sui, Adramelech, et Sarasar filii ejus percusserunt eum gladio, fugeruntque in terram Armeniorum. Et regnavit Asarhaddon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: And as he was worshipping in the temple of Nisroch, his pagan god, Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, struck him down with the sword. They then fled into the land of Armenia. And Esarhaddon, his son, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum audisset rex Ezechias, scidit vestimenta sua, et obvolutus est sacco, et intravit in domum Domini.
verses.english: When King Hezekiah heard this message of blasphemy and threat, he tore his royal garments in a display of profound grief and lamentation. He then wrapped himself in sackcloth, as a visible sign of his humility and penitence before God. After this, he immediately went into the Temple of the Lord to seek divine counsel.

verses.latin: Et misit Eliacim, qui erat super domum, et Sobnam scribam, et seniores de sacerdotibus, obvolutos sacco, ad Isaiam prophetam, filium Amos.
verses.english: King Hezekiah sent Eliakim, who was the royal steward in charge of the palace, along with Shebna the royal secretary, and the most senior priests—all of whom were also dressed in sackcloth as a sign of their shared national distress—to the prophet Isaiah, the son of Amoz, to seek a prophetic word from God.

verses.latin: Qui dixerunt ei: Hæc dicit Ezechias: Dies tribulationis, et increpationis, et blasphemiæ, dies ista: quia venerunt filii usque ad partum, et vires non sunt parienti.
verses.english: These men then reported to Isaiah King Hezekiah's words: 'This day is a day of deep affliction, of severe rebuke from God, and of direct blasphemy against His holy Name, hurled by the Assyrians. Our nation is in such a desperate state, like a woman in labor who has reached the point of birth but lacks the strength to deliver her child—we are at the brink of destruction with no power to save ourselves.'

verses.latin: Si quomodo audiat Dominus Deus tuus omnia verba Rabsacis, quem misit rex Assyriorum dominus suus, ut exprobraret Deum viventem, et arguat verba quæ audivit Dominus Deus tuus: leva ergo orationem pro reliquiis quæ repertæ sunt.
verses.english: 'Perhaps the Lord your God has heard all the words of Rabshakeh, whom the King of Assyria, his master, sent to mock and insult the living God, and the Lord your God will condemn these words that He heard: please, then, raise up a fervent prayer for the small remnant of our people who are still left and found alive.'

verses.latin: Venerunt ergo servi regis Ezechiæ ad Isaiam.
verses.english: So, the servants of King Hezekiah—Eliakim, Shebna, and the senior priests—came before the prophet Isaiah.

verses.latin: Et dixit eis Isaias: Hæc dicetis domino vestro: Hæc dicit Dominus: Noli timere a facie sermonum quos audisti, quibus blasphemaverunt pueri regis Assyriorum me.
verses.english: And Isaiah declared to them, 'Tell your master, King Hezekiah, this message from the Lord: 'Do not be afraid because of the words you have heard—the blasphemous insults uttered against Me by the servants of the King of Assyria. These are mere human words, but they are an affront to the living God.''

verses.latin: Ecce ego immittam ei spiritum, et audiet nuntium, et revertetur in terram suam, et dejiciam eum gladio in terra sua.
verses.english: 'Indeed, I am now going to put a spirit into him—a spirit of fear and urgency—so that when he hears a report about his homeland, he will immediately return to his own country. And there, in his own land, I will cause him to fall by the sword; he will meet a violent end.'

verses.latin: Reversus est itaque Rabsaces, et invenit regem Assyriorum juxta Lobnam: confestim enim audierat quia recessisset de Lachis.
verses.english: So Rabshakeh, the Assyrian general, returned to his king, Sennacherib, and found him battling near Libnah. This was because Rabshakeh had already heard that the Assyrian king had withdrawn from his siege of Lachish.

verses.latin: Audierat enim de Tharaca rege Æthiopiæ, dicentes: Ecce egressus est ut pugnet adversum te. Et rursum misit nuntios ad Ezechiam, dicens:
verses.english: Now, King Sennacherib had received a report concerning Tirhakah, the King of Ethiopia (also known as the Kushite King), stating: 'Indeed, he has marched out to wage war against you.' Because of this new threat, Sennacherib once again sent messengers to King Hezekiah of Judah, instructing them with a new message, saying:

verses.latin: Hæc dicetis Ezechiæ regi Juda: Non te seducat Deus tuus, in quo habes fiduciam, dicens: Non dabitur Jerusalem in manus regis Assyriorum.
verses.english: 'Say this to King Hezekiah of Judah: 'Do not let your God, in whom you place your trust and confidence, deceive you by saying: 'Jerusalem will not be handed over into the power of the King of Assyria.' Do not be misled by such false hope.''

verses.latin: Ecce audisti quæ fecerint reges Assyriorum universis terris, quam magnifice vastaverint eas: et tu poteris liberari?
verses.english: 'Look, you have heard and know very well what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other countries they have conquered, and how utterly and powerfully they have devastated them and brought them to ruin. So, do you truly believe that you alone will be able to be delivered from our grasp?'

verses.latin: Numquid liberaverunt dii gentium singulos, quos vastaverunt patres mei, Gozan, et Charan, et Reseph, et filios Eden qui erant in Thelassar?
verses.english: 'Have the false gods of the nations—each one of them—been able to deliver their people whom my forefathers destroyed? Have they saved Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, or the people of Eden who lived in Telassar? No, they have not!'

verses.latin: Ubi est rex Emath, et rex Arphad, et rex urbis Sepharvaim, Ana, et Ava?
verses.english: 'Where are the kings of Hamath and Arpad now? And where is the king of the city of Sepharvaim? And where are the kings of Hena and Ivvah? They are all gone, conquered by my armies, and their gods could not save them!'

verses.latin: Suscepit itaque Ezechias libros de manu nuntiorum, et legit illos: et ascendit in domum Domini, et expandit eos Ezechias coram Domino.
verses.english: King Hezekiah received these threatening letters from the messengers and read their blasphemous contents. He then went up into the Temple of the Lord, and there, in a powerful act of supplication and faith, Hezekiah spread out the letters before the Lord God.

verses.latin: Et oravit in conspectu Domini, dicens: Domine Deus Israël, qui sedes super cherubim, tu es Deus solus omnium regnorum terræ: tu fecisti cælum et terram.
verses.english: And Hezekiah prayed fervently in the sight of the Lord, declaring: 'O Lord, the God of Israel, You who are enthroned above the cherubim—You alone are the one true God of all the kingdoms and nations of the earth. You are the Almighty Creator, for You made the entire universe and the earth!'

verses.latin: Inclina, Domine, aurem tuam, et audi: aperi, Domine, oculos tuos, et vide: et audi omnia verba Sennacherib, quæ misit ut exprobraret nobis Deum viventem.
verses.english: 'Incline Your ear, O Lord, and hear our plea! Open Your divine eyes, O Lord, and see our distress! Hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he sent to mock and insult You, the living God, and thereby bring shame upon us, Your people.'

verses.latin: Vere enim, Domine, vastaverunt reges Assyriorum gentes, et terras omnium.
verses.english: 'It is true, O Lord, that the kings of Assyria have indeed laid waste to the nations and all their lands, just as their arrogant letter boasts.'

verses.latin: Et miserunt deos eorum in ignem: non enim erant dii, sed opera manuum hominum de lignis et lapidibus, et perdiderunt eos.
verses.english: 'And they have thrown the false gods of those nations into the fire and destroyed them. But these so-called gods were not truly gods at all; they were merely the lifeless work of human hands, fashioned from wood and stone, and thus the Assyrians were able to easily destroy them.'

verses.latin: Nunc igitur, Domine Deus noster, salvos nos fac de manu ejus, ut sciant omnia regna terræ quia tu es Dominus Deus solus.
verses.english: 'Now therefore, O Lord our God, we humbly pray: deliver us from the powerful hand of this Assyrian king, Sennacherib. Do this so that all the kingdoms and nations of the earth may come to know and acknowledge that You alone are the Lord God, the one true and living God!'

verses.latin: Misit autem Isaias, filius Amos, ad Ezechiam, dicens: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Quæ deprecatus es me super Sennacherib regem Assyriorum, audivi.
verses.english: Then Isaiah, the son of Amoz, sent a message back to King Hezekiah, saying: 'This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, declares: 'I have heard your earnest prayer concerning Sennacherib, the King of Assyria. Your petition has reached My ears.''

verses.latin: Iste est sermo, quem locutus est Dominus de eo: Sprevit te, et derisit te virgo filia Sion: post te caput suum movit filia Jerusalem.
verses.english: 'This is the divine word which the Lord has spoken concerning Sennacherib: 'The virgin daughter of Zion—meaning the city of Jerusalem, pristine and undefiled by conquest—despises you and scoffs at your threats! The daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head in defiant scorn at you, King Sennacherib!''

verses.latin: Quem exprobrasti, et quem blasphemasti? contra quem exaltasti vocem, et elevasti in excelsum oculos tuos? contra Sanctum Israël.
verses.english: 'Whom have you mocked and insulted with your words? Against whom have you raised your voice in arrogance, and lifted your eyes in proud defiance? You have done this against the Holy One of Israel Himself!'

verses.latin: Per manus nuntiorum tuorum exprobrasti Domino, et dixisti: In multitudine curruum meorum ascendi excelsa montium, juga Libani: et succidi excelsa cedrorum ejus, et electas abietes ejus, et ingressus sum usque ad terminos ejus, saltum Carmeli ejus.
verses.english: 'By the hands of your messengers, you have indeed mocked the Lord God, and you have arrogantly declared: 'With my vast chariots and my mighty army, I have ascended the highest mountain peaks, even the very summits of Lebanon! I have cut down its tallest cedars and its finest cypress trees, and I have penetrated deep into its farthest reaches, into its most fertile forest, like its glorious Carmel!''

verses.latin: Ego succidi, et bibi aquas alienas, et siccavi vestigio pedis mei omnes rivos aggerum.
verses.english: 'You have further boasted: 'I have personally dug wells and drunk foreign waters in conquered lands, and with the sole of my foot, I have dried up all the fortified streams of Egypt!' Your arrogance knows no bounds, thinking your power is limitless.

verses.latin: Numquid non audisti quia a longe feci illud, ex diebus antiquis plasmavi illud? et nunc adduxi illud: et factum est in ruinam collium compugnantium, et civitatum munitarum.
verses.english: 'Have you not heard, King Sennacherib, that I, the Lord, have ordained this from long ago? From ancient times, I planned it, shaping and forming it according to My divine will. And now, I have brought it to pass: that you would turn fortified cities into piles of rubble, becoming a ruin of warring hills and strong cities, all as part of My grand design!'

verses.latin: Et qui sederunt in eis, brevi manu, contremuerunt et confusi sunt: facti sunt sicut fœnum agri, et pabulum viride, tecta domorum, et arefacta ut herba.
verses.english: 'Therefore, the inhabitants of those conquered lands had little power to resist; they were utterly dismayed and disgraced. They became like the grass of the field and the tender green plants, easily withered; like the thin grass on rooftops, scorched and dried up before it grows tall.'

verses.latin: Habitaculum tuum, et egressum tuum, et introitum tuum, et viam tuam ego præscivi: et insaniam tuam contra me.
verses.english: 'But I, the Lord, know your every move: your comings and goings, your habitation, your entire way of life, and your journeying—I know all of it! And I also know the raging madness and fury that you direct against Me, the living God!'

verses.latin: Cum fureres contra me, et superbia tua ascendisset in aures meas, ponam circulum in naribus tuis, et frenum in labiis tuis, et reducam te in viam, per quam venisti.
verses.english: 'Because you have raged against Me, and your arrogant boasting has ascended into My ears, I will place a hook in your nose and a bridle in your lips, just as one would do to a wild, untamed beast. And I will turn you back and lead you away along the very road by which you came, forcing your retreat!'

verses.latin: Tibi autem hoc erit signum: Comedite hoc anno quæ reperire poteritis: et in anno secundo, quæ sponte nascuntur: in anno autem tertio seminate, et metite, plantate vineas, et comedite fructus earum.
verses.english: 'And this, O King Hezekiah, will be a miraculous sign for you and your people that My promise is true: This year, you will eat what grows naturally from scattered seeds left over from the previous harvest. And in the second year, you will eat what springs up from the ground on its own, without cultivation. But in the third year, you will once again be able to sow seed and reap a proper harvest, and you will plant vineyards and eat their fruits in peace.'

verses.latin: Et addet id quod evaserit de domo Juda, et quod reliquum fuerit, radices suas deorsum, et faciet fructum sursum.
verses.english: 'And the remnant that has escaped from the House of Judah—those who remain faithful and alive—will again take deep root downward into the land, and they will produce abundant fruit upward, signifying spiritual and physical prosperity.'

verses.latin: De Jerusalem quippe egredietur salvatio, et quod reliquum est de monte Sion: zelus Domini exercituum faciet hoc.
verses.english: 'For from Jerusalem will come forth a saving remnant, and those who remain alive from Mount Zion—they will be preserved. The fervent zeal and passionate determination of the Lord of Hosts, the Commander of heavenly armies, will accomplish this divine intervention!'

verses.latin: Propterea hæc dicit Dominus de rege Assyriorum: Non ingredietur urbem hanc, nec mittet in eam sagittam, nec occupabit eam clypeus, nec fundet circa eam aggerem.
verses.english: Therefore, this is what the Lord declares concerning the King of Assyria: 'He shall not enter this holy city of Jerusalem; he will not even shoot an arrow into it. No shield will be raised against it, nor will he build a siege ramp against its walls, for I will protect it absolutely.'

verses.latin: In via qua venit, per eam revertetur: et civitatem hanc non ingredietur, dicit Dominus.
verses.english: 'By the very road he came, by that same road will he return in retreat. He shall not enter this city,' declares the Lord, the Almighty God.

verses.latin: Et protegam civitatem hanc, et salvabo eam propter me, et propter David servum meum.
verses.english: 'For I will protect this city, and I will save it, not for their merit, but for My own honor and glory, and for the sake of My loyal servant, King David, and the covenant I made with him.'

verses.latin: Factum est igitur in nocte illa, venit angelus Domini, et percussit in castris Assyriorum centum octoginta quinque millia. Cumque surrexissent diluculo, viderunt omnia corpora mortuorum.
verses.english: So, it came to pass on that very night, that an angel of the Lord—a powerful heavenly messenger—went out and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand men in the Assyrian military camp. When the remaining Assyrians rose early the next morning, they looked out and saw all these vast numbers of dead bodies, realizing a catastrophic supernatural event had occurred.

verses.latin: Et recessit, et abiit Sennacherib rex Assyriorum: et reversus est, et mansit in Ninive.
verses.english: Then King Sennacherib of Assyria broke camp and departed immediately. He retreated from the land of Judah, returned to his own territory, and settled in his capital city, Nineveh.

verses.latin: Cumque adoraret in templo Nesroch dæmonis sui, Adramelech et Sarasar filii ejus percusserunt eum gladio, fugeruntque in terram Armeniorum: et regnavit Asarhaddon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: And it happened that while Sennacherib was worshipping in the temple of Nisroch, his demon-god, his own sons, Adrammelech and Sharezer, struck him down with a sword and killed him. They then fled for their lives to the land of Armenia. And Esarhaddon, another of Sennacherib's sons, became king in his place.

verses.latin: In diebus illis Ezechias ægrotavit usque ad mortem: et introivit ad eum Isaias filius Amos propheta, et dixit ei: Hæc dicit Dominus: Dispone domui tuæ, quia morieris tu, et non vives.
verses.english: In those days, King Hezekiah became so sick he was going to die. The prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, went in to see him and said, "This is what the Lord says: Set your affairs in order, because you will die and not live."

verses.latin: Qui convertit faciem suam ad parietem, et oravit Dominum, dicens:
verses.english: Hezekiah turned his face towards the wall and prayed to the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Obsecro, Domine, memento, quæso, quomodo ambulaverim coram te in veritate, et in corde perfecto, et quod placitum est coram te fecerim. Flevit itaque Ezechias fletu magno.
verses.english: "I beg you, Lord, please remember, I pray, how I have walked before you in truth and with a perfect heart, and how I have done what was pleasing in your sight." And Hezekiah wept with great sorrow.

verses.latin: Et factum est, antequam egrederetur Isaias mediam partem atrii, sermo Domini factus est ad eum, dicens:
verses.english: And it happened, before Isaiah had even left the middle part of the courtyard, that the word of the Lord came to him, saying:

verses.latin: Revertere, et dic Ezechiæ duci populi mei: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus David patris tui: Audivi orationem tuam, et vidi lacrimas tuas: ecce ego adjiciam super dies tuos quindecim annos:
verses.english: Go back, and tell Hezekiah, the leader of my people: "This is what the Lord, the God of your father David, says: I have heard your prayer and I have seen your tears. Indeed, I will add fifteen years to your life."

verses.latin: et de manu regis Assyriorum liberabo te, et civitatem hanc, et protegam civitatem istam.
verses.english: And I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of the Assyrians, and I will protect this city.

verses.latin: Dixitque Isaias: Afferte massam ficorum. Quam cum attulissent, et posuissent super ulcus ejus, curatus est.
verses.english: Then Isaiah said, "Bring a poultice of figs." When they brought it and applied it to his boil, he recovered.

verses.latin: Dixerat autem Ezechias ad Isaiam: Quod signum, quia sanabit me Dominus, et ascendam tertia die in templum Domini?
verses.english: Now Hezekiah had said to Isaiah, "What will be the sign that the Lord will heal me and that I will go up to the Temple of the Lord on the third day?"

verses.latin: Cui respondit Isaias: Hoc erit signum a Domino, quod faciat Dominus verbum quod locutus est: vis ut ascendat umbra decem lineis, an revertatur totidem gradibus?
verses.english: Isaiah answered him, "This will be the sign from the Lord, that the Lord will do what He has promised: Do you want the shadow to advance ten steps, or to go back ten steps?"

verses.latin: Et ait Ezechias: Facile est umbram descendere decem lineis: nec hoc volo, ut fiat, sed ut revertatur umbra retrorsum decem gradibus.
verses.english: Hezekiah said, "It is easy for the shadow to move forward ten steps, but I do not want that. Instead, let the shadow move back ten steps."

verses.latin: Et invocavit Isaias propheta Dominum: et reduxit umbram per decem lineas, per quas jam descenderat in horologio Achaz.
verses.english: Then the prophet Isaiah called upon the Lord, and God made the shadow on the sundial of Ahaz go back ten steps, which it had already descended.

verses.latin: In tempore illo misit Berodach Baladan filius Baladan rex Babyloniorum litteras et munera Ezechiæ: audierat enim quod ægrotasset Ezechias.
verses.english: At that time, Berodach-Baladan, son of Baladan, the king of the Babylonians, sent letters and gifts to King Hezekiah, for he had heard that Hezekiah had been sick.

verses.latin: Audivitque eos Ezechias, et ostendit eis omnes thesauros domus suæ, argentum et aurum, et aromata, et unguenta pretiosa, et domum vasorum suorum, et universa quæ habere potuerat in thesauris suis. Non fuit quod non monstraret eis Ezechias in domo sua, et in omni potestate sua.
verses.english: Hezekiah heard what they had to say, and then he showed them all the treasures of his palace: the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oils, his armory, and everything that could be found in his treasuries. There was nothing in his palace or in all his dominion that Hezekiah did not show them.

verses.latin: Introivit autem Isaias propheta ad regem Ezechiam, dixitque ei: Quid dixerunt viri isti? aut unde venerunt ad te? Cui ait Ezechias: De terra longinqua venerunt de Babylone.
verses.english: Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and asked him, "What did these men say, and where did they come from?" Hezekiah replied, "They came from a distant land, from Babylon."

verses.latin: Et ait: Quid viderunt in domo tua? Respondit Ezechias: Omnia quæ in domo mea sunt viderunt: non fuit quicquam quod non monstrarem eis in thesauris meis.
verses.english: Isaiah then asked, "What did they see in your palace?" Hezekiah answered, "They saw everything that is in my palace. There was nothing in my treasuries that I did not show them."

verses.latin: Dixitque Isaias ad Ezechiam: Audi sermonem Domini.
verses.english: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, "Hear the word of the Lord."

verses.latin: Ecce dies veniunt, et auferentur omnia quæ in domo tua sunt, et quæ thesaurizaverunt patres tui usque in diem hanc, in Babylonem: non relinquetur quicquam, dicit Dominus.
verses.english: Behold, the days are coming when everything in your palace, and everything that your ancestors have stored up until this day, will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left, says the Lord.

verses.latin: Et de filiis tuis, qui egredientur de te, quos generabis, tollent, et erunt eunuchi in palatio regis Babylonis.
verses.english: And some of your sons, who will come from you, whom you will father, will be taken and made eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.

verses.latin: Et ait Ezechias ad Isaiam: Bonus sermo Domini, quem locutus es: fiat pax et veritas in diebus meis.
verses.english: Hezekiah said to Isaiah, "The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good. Let there be peace and stability during my lifetime."

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Ezechiæ, et omnis fortitudo ejus, et quomodo fecit piscinam et aquæductum, et introduxit aquas in civitatem, nonne hæc scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Juda?
verses.english: As for the rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and all his might, and how he made the pool and the aqueduct and brought water into the city—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?

verses.latin: Dormivitque Ezechias cum patribus suis, et regnavit Manasses filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: And Hezekiah slept with his ancestors, and his son Manasseh reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Manasses erat duodecim annorum cum regnare cœpisset, et quinquaginta quinque annis regnavit in Jerusalem: nomen matris ejus Hepsiba.
verses.english: Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign. He reigned for fifty-five years in Jerusalem. The name of his mother was Hephzibah.

verses.latin: Fecitque quod malum erat in conspectu Domini, juxta idola gentium quas subvertit Dominus a facie filiorum Israël.
verses.english: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, following the abominable practices of the pagan nations that the Lord had driven out from before the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Convertit enim et ædificavit excelsa quæ dissipaverat Ezechias pater ejus: et erexit aras Baal, et fecit lucos, sicut fecerat Achab rex Israël: et adoravit omnem militiam cæli, et coluit eam.
verses.english: For he rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed. He set up altars for Baal and made sacred groves, just as Ahab, the king of Israel, had done. Manasseh also worshipped all the celestial bodies of the sky, serving them as gods.

verses.latin: Et ædificavit aras in domo Domini, de qua dixit Dominus: In Jerusalem ponam nomen meum.
verses.english: He built altars in the Temple of the Lord, regarding which the Lord had said: “In Jerusalem I will establish my presence.”

verses.latin: Et ædificavit aras universæ militiæ cæli in duobus atriis templi Domini.
verses.english: He built altars for all the celestial bodies of the sky in both courtyards of the Temple of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et transduxit filium suum per ignem: et ariolatus est, et observavit somnia, et exercuit auguria, et fecit pythonas, et maleficos multiplicavit, ut faceret malum coram Domino, et irritaret eum.
verses.english: He also made his son pass through fire as a sacrifice, consulted diviners, practiced sorcery, engaged in witchcraft, and greatly multiplied those who consulted familiar spirits and wizards. He did much evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking Him to anger.

verses.latin: Posuit quoque simulacrum luci, quam fecerat, in templo Domini, super quod locutus est Dominus ad David, et ad Salomonem filium ejus, dicens: In templo hoc, et in Jerusalem, quam elegi de cunctis tribubus Israël, ponam nomen meum in sempiternum.
verses.english: He placed an idol of the sacred grove, which he had made, in the Temple of the Lord. Regarding this Temple, the Lord had said to David and to his son Solomon: “In this Temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel, I will establish my name forever.”

verses.latin: Et non faciam ultra commoveri pedem Israël de terra quam dedi patribus eorum: ita dumtaxat si custodierint opera mea, et universam legem quam præcepi eis per servum meum Moysen.
verses.english: And I will no longer allow the feet of Israel to wander from the land which I gave to their fathers—that is, if they will carefully observe my commandments and the entire Law that I commanded them through my servant Moses.

verses.latin: Illi vero non audierunt: sed seduxit eos Manasses, ut facerent malum super gentes quas contrivit Dominus a facie filiorum Israël.
verses.english: But they did not listen. Instead, Manasseh misled them to do more evil than the pagan nations whom the Lord had destroyed before the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus per servos suos prophetas, dicens:
verses.english: Then the Lord spoke through His servants, the prophets, saying:

verses.latin: Quia fecit Manasses rex Juda abominationes istas pessimam, super omnia quæ fecerunt Amorrhæi ante eum: et peccare fecit etiam Judam in idolis suis:
verses.english: “Because Manasseh, the king of Judah, has committed these most wicked abominations—doing more evil than all the Amorites before him—and has also made Judah sin with his idols,

verses.latin: propterea hæc dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Ecce ego inducam mala super Jerusalem et Judam, ut quicumque audierit, tinniant ambæ aures ejus.
verses.english: therefore, this is what the Lord God of Israel says: 'Behold, I am bringing such disaster upon Jerusalem and Judah that the ears of everyone who hears about it will ring with terror.

verses.latin: Et extendam super Jerusalem funiculum Samariæ, et pondus domus Achab: et delebo Jerusalem, sicut deleri solent tabulæ, et delens vertam, et ducam stilum super faciem ejus.
verses.english: I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line of Samaria and the plumb line of the house of Ahab. I will wipe away Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down.

verses.latin: Et dimittam reliquias hæreditatis meæ, et dabo eos in manu inimicorum suorum: et erunt in vastitatem, et in rapinam cunctis adversariis suis,
verses.english: And I will abandon the remnant of my heritage, delivering them into the hand of their enemies. They will become plunder and a prey to all their adversaries,

verses.latin: eo quod fecerint malum coram me, et provocaverint me, ex die qua egressi sunt patres eorum de Ægypto usque ad hanc diem.
verses.english: because they have done evil in my sight and have provoked me to anger, from the day their fathers came out of Egypt until this very day.’”

verses.latin: Insuper et sanguinem innoxium fudit Manasses multum nimis, donec impleret Jerusalem a summo usque ad novissimum: absque peccatis suis quibus peccare fecit Judam, ut faceret malum coram Domino.
verses.english: Moreover, Manasseh shed so much innocent blood that he filled Jerusalem from one end to the other. This was in addition to his sins by which he made Judah sin and do evil in the sight of the Lord.

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Manasse, et universa quæ fecit, et peccatum ejus quod peccavit, nonne hæc scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Juda?
verses.english: Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, and all that he did, and the sin he committed, are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?

verses.latin: Dormivitque Manasses cum patribus suis, et sepultus est in horto domus suæ, in horto Oza: et regnavit Amon filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: Manasseh rested with his fathers and was buried in the garden of his own house, in the Garden of Uzza. And his son Amon reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Viginti duorum annorum erat Amon cum regnare cœpisset, et duobus annis regnavit in Jerusalem: nomen matris ejus Messalemeth filia Haros de Jeteba.
verses.english: Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign. He reigned for two years in Jerusalem. The name of his mother was Meshullemeth, the daughter of Haruz, from Jotbah.

verses.latin: Fecitque quod malum erat in conspectu Domini, sicut fecerat Manasses pater ejus.
verses.english: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as his father Manasseh had done.

verses.latin: Et ambulavit in omni via per quam ambulaverat pater ejus: et servivit immunditiis quibus servierat pater ejus, et adoravit eas.
verses.english: He walked in every way that his father had walked. He served the detestable idols that his father had served and worshipped them.

verses.latin: Et dereliquit Dominum Deum patrum suorum, et non ambulavit in via Domini.
verses.english: He abandoned the Lord, the God of his fathers, and did not walk in the way of the Lord.

verses.latin: Conjuraverunt autem servi Amon contra eum, et interfecerunt regem in domo sua.
verses.english: Now the servants of Amon conspired against him and killed the king in his own house.

verses.latin: Percussitque populus terræ omnes qui conjuraverant contra regem Amon: et fecerunt regem Josiam filium ejus pro eo.
verses.english: But the people of the land struck down all those who had conspired against King Amon. Then they made his son Josiah king in his place.

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Amon quæ fecit, nonne hæc scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Juda?
verses.english: Now the rest of the acts of Amon which he did, are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?

verses.latin: Et sepelierunt eum in sepulchro suo in horto Oza: et regnavit Josias filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: They buried him in his tomb in the Garden of Uzza. And his son Josiah reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Octo annorum erat Josias cum regnare cœpisset, et triginta uno anno regnavit in Jerusalem: nomen matris ejus Idida filia Adaja de Besecath.
verses.english: Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign. He reigned for thirty-one years in Jerusalem. The name of his mother was Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah, from Bozkath.

verses.latin: Et fecit quod rectum erat in conspectu Domini, et ambulavit in omni via David patris sui: non declinavit ad dexteram, neque ad sinistram.
verses.english: And he did what was right in the sight of the Lord. He walked in all the ways of his father David, not turning aside to the right or to the left.

verses.latin: Anno autem octavo regni sui, cum adhuc esset puer, cœpit quærere Deum patris sui David: et duodecimo anno cœpit mundare Judam et Jerusalem ab excelsis, et lucis, et sculptilibus, et conflatilibus.
verses.english: Now in the eighth year of his reign, while he was still a boy, he began to seek the God of his father David. In the twelfth year of his reign, he began to cleanse Judah and Jerusalem of the high places, the sacred groves, the carved idols, and the molten images.

verses.latin: Destruxeruntque coram eo aras Baalim, et simulacra quæ superposita fuerant, demolitus est: lucosque et sculptilia succidit, et comminuit in frusta: et campos idolorum contrivit, et pulverem eorum jactavit super sepulchra eorum qui immolaverant.
verses.english: Before him, they tore down the altars of the Baals, and he smashed the altars that were placed above them. He cut down the sacred groves and the carved idols, breaking them into pieces. He pulverized the idol fields and scattered their dust over the tombs of those who had offered sacrifices there.

verses.latin: Aras quoque idolorum combussit in circuitu, et succidit lucos, et sculptilia et conflatilia comminuit in pulverem, et jactavit super sepulchra pauperum.
verses.english: He also burned the altars of the idols all around, cut down the sacred groves, and crushed the carved and molten images into dust. He scattered the dust over the graves of the common people.

verses.latin: Similiter autem fecit in civitatibus Manasse, et Ephraim, et Simeon, et usque ad Nephthali, cunctis per circuitum idololatria demolita.
verses.english: He did likewise in the cities of Manasseh, Ephraim, and Simeon, and as far as Naphtali, destroying idolatry throughout the surrounding areas.

verses.latin: Cumque reversus esset in Jerusalem, transiens templum Domini, invenit librum legis manus Domini per Moysen in domo Domini.
verses.english: When he returned to Jerusalem, passing through the Temple of the Lord, he found the book of the Law of the Lord given through Moses in the Temple of the Lord.

verses.latin: Hoc est quod invenit Hilias sacerdos, et dedit Saphano scribæ, et ille legit in conspectu regis.
verses.english: This is what Hilkiah the priest found and gave to Shaphan the scribe, and he read it in the presence of the king.

verses.latin: Cumque audisset verba legis Domini, rex scidit vestimenta sua, et oravit Dominum.
verses.english: When the king heard the words of the Law of the Lord, he tore his garments and prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Et præcepit Hiliæ sacerdoti, et Achicam filio Saphani, et Abdon filio Michæ, et Saphano scribæ, et Asaæ servo regis, dicens:
verses.english: Then he commanded Hilkiah the priest, and Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, and Abdon, the son of Micah, and Shaphan the scribe, and Asaiah, the king’s servant, saying:

verses.latin: Ite, et consulite Dominum de me, et de populo, et de universo Juda, super verbis libri hujus qui inventus est: grandis enim est ira Domini quæ effusa est super nos, eo quod non custodierint patres nostri verba Domini, ut facerent omnia quæ scripta sunt in libro isto.
verses.english: “Go, inquire of the Lord for me, and for the people, and for all Judah, concerning the words of this book that has been found. For great is the wrath of the Lord that has been poured out upon us, because our fathers have not kept the words of the Lord to do everything written in this book.”

verses.latin: Abiit itaque Hilias sacerdos, et Achicam, et Abdon, et Saphan, et Asaæ ad Holdam prophetissam, uxorem Sellum filii Thecuath filii Hasra custodis vestium, quæ habitabat in Jerusalem in secunda, et locuti sunt ei verba quæ supra diximus.
verses.english: So Hilkiah the priest, and Ahikam, and Abdon, and Shaphan, and Asaiah, went to Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum, the son of Tikvah, the son of Harhas, the keeper of the wardrobe. She lived in Jerusalem in the Second Quarter. They spoke to her the words that had been previously said to them.

verses.latin: Quæ respondit illis: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Dicite viro qui misit vos ad me:
verses.english: And she answered them: “Thus says the Lord God of Israel: ‘Tell the man who sent you to me:

verses.latin: Hæc dicit Dominus: Ecce ego inducam mala super locum istum, et super habitatores ejus, omnia maledicta quæ scripta sunt in libro hoc quem legerunt coram rege Juda:
verses.english: “This is what the Lord says: 'Behold, I will bring disaster upon this place and upon its inhabitants, all the curses that are written in this book which they have read before the king of Judah.

verses.latin: Octo annorum erat Josias cum regnare cœpisset, et triginta uno annos regnavit in Jerusalem. Nomen matris ejus Idida filia Adaja de Besecath.
verses.english: Josias was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned for thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Idida, daughter of Adaja, from the town of Besecath.

verses.latin: Fecitque quod rectum est in oculis Domini, et ambulavit in omni via David patris sui: non declinavit nec ad dexteram, nec ad sinistram.
verses.english: He did what was right in the eyes of the Lord. He walked in the full path of his father David, not turning aside to the right or to the left.

verses.latin: Decimo octavo autem anno regni regis Josiæ, misit rex Saphan filium Asaliæ filii Messulam scribam templi Domini, dicens:
verses.english: In the eighteenth year of King Josias's reign, the king sent Saphan, son of Asaliah, son of Messulam, who was the scribe of the Lord's Temple, saying:

verses.latin: Vade ad Helciam sacerdotem magnum, ut expendat pecuniam quæ illata est in templum Domini, quam collegerunt janitores a populo,
verses.english: "Go to Helcias, the high priest. Tell him to assess the money that has been brought into the Lord's Temple. This money was collected by the doorkeepers from the people."

verses.latin: detque eam fabris, et cementariis, et his qui intercidunt lapides, et ut emant ligna, et lapides de cæsis ædificent templum Domini.
verses.english: "And let him give this money to the carpenters, and to the masons, and to those who cut stones. Let them also buy wood and cut stones so that they may repair and rebuild the Temple of the Lord."

verses.latin: Non veniebat ratio cum eis pecuniæ quæ accipiebant, sed in fide agebant.
verses.english: There was no accounting required with them for the money they received, because they acted with faithfulness and integrity.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Helcias pontifex ad Saphan scribam: Librum legis inveni in domo Domini. Deditque Helcias librum Saphan, et legit illum.
verses.english: Then Helcias the high priest said to Saphan the scribe, "I have found the Book of the Law in the house of the Lord." And Helcias gave the book to Saphan, who then read it.

verses.latin: Venitque Saphan scriba ad regem, et retulit ei quod præceperat: et postea indicavit ei, dicens: Librum dedit mihi Helcias sacerdos. Quem cum legisset Saphan coram rege,
verses.english: Saphan the scribe came to the king and reported what the king had commanded him. Afterwards, Saphan informed the king, saying, "Helcias the priest gave me a book." When Saphan read the book aloud before the king,

verses.latin: et audisset rex sermones libri legis Domini, scidit vestimenta sua.
verses.english: and the king heard the words of the book, which was the Law of the Lord, he tore his clothes in grief and repentance.

verses.latin: Et præcepit Helciæ sacerdoti, et Achicam filio Saphan, et Achobor filio Micha, et Saphan scribæ, et Asaæ servo regis, dicens:
verses.english: And he commanded Helcias the priest, and Achicam the son of Saphan, and Achobor the son of Micha, and Saphan the scribe, and Asaiah the king's servant, saying:

verses.latin: Ite, et consulite Dominum super me, et super populo, et super omni Juda, de sermonibus libri hujus qui inventus est: grandis enim ira Domini succensa est contra nos, quia non audierunt patres nostri verba libri hujus, ut facerent omne quod scriptum est nobis.
verses.english: "Go and consult the Lord on my behalf, and on behalf of the people, and on behalf of all Judah, concerning the words of this book that has been found. For the great wrath of the Lord has been kindled against us, because our fathers did not listen to the words of this book, so as to do all that is written and commanded for us."

verses.latin: Abierunt itaque Helcias sacerdos, et Achicam, et Achobor, et Saphan, et Asaæ, ad Oldam prophetissam uxorem Sellum filii Thecue filii Araas custodis vestium, quæ habitabat in Jerusalem in secunda, locutique sunt ad eam.
verses.english: So Helcias the priest, and Achicam, and Achobor, and Saphan, and Asaiah, went to Olda the prophetess. She was the wife of Sellum, son of Thecue, son of Araas, the keeper of the vestments. She was living in Jerusalem in the Second Quarter. They spoke to her, seeking guidance.

verses.latin: Et illa respondit eis: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Dicite viro qui misit vos ad me:
verses.english: And she answered them, saying, "Thus says the Lord God of Israel: 'Tell the man who sent you to me:

verses.latin: Hæc dicit Dominus: Ecce ego inducam mala super locum hunc, et super habitatores ejus, omnia verba libri quæ legit rex Juda:
verses.english: Thus says the Lord: Behold, I will bring evil upon this place and upon its inhabitants—all the words of the book which the king of Judah has read. This punishment will certainly come to pass."
